body_text.text: Background Echocardiography typically used to delineate the anatomy of the pulmonary venous drainage and the septum. But sometimes it is difficult to detect the pulmonary vein confluence by echocardiography and catheter-based angiography. CT and MRI may be used to further delineate the cardiac anatomy. Several previous reports showed that CTA has some advantages when compared to other imaging modalities. On the contrary of catheter angiography, it is a non-invasive technique. In addition, it has more spatial resolution than MRI. Objective To evaluate the value of multidtector computed tomography in the diadnosis of Partial Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Return. Materials and methods A 11-year-old male was admitted to the our Paediatric Cardiology Unit for a cardiac murmur. Transthoracic echocardiography showed mild dilatation of the right atrium and the right ventricle with increased superior caval vein flow and minimum secundum atrial septal defect. This examination revealed two of four pulmonary veins draining into the left atrium. It was suspected supracardiac partial abnormal pulmonary venous return. The patient was referred to our multidetector computed tomography (MDCT) department for preoperative further evaluation of vascular abnormalities. MDCT was performed on a 64-detector-row CT scanner (Aquillon; Toshiba Medical Systems, Tokyo, Japan). After scanning, we transferred the MDCT data sets to an independent workstation (Vitrea, Toshiba) for postprocessing CT angiography (CTA). Results CTA confirmed that right pulmonary veins connect to the innominate vein with subsequent drainage to the right superior vena cava and to the right atrium (Fig. 1) . These findings were confirmed at operation. Conclusion In conclusion, as the role of CTA as a imaging modality is increasing, rare congenital heart disease such as PAPVR need to be recognized on MDCT.

Multidetector CT findings of a case with Tetralogy of Fallot with left pulmonary artery atresia Nilay Akhun, Yonca Anık, Nagihan Inan, Sevtap Gumustas, Ali Demirci Radiology Department, Kocaeli University Hospital Background Tetralogy of fallot in an anomaly respresenting with infundibular right ventricular outflow obstruction, subaortic ventric-ular septal defect, right ventricular hypertrophy and dekstraposition of the aorta. Objective In this case, our purpose is to represent 64 detectors CT findings of the tetralogy of fallot with left pulmonary artery atresia and right pulmonary artery reconstruction after surgery. Materials and methods In this case, we respresented detailed 64 detectors CT muliplanar reformatted and three dimentional images of the tetralogy of the fallot findings, left pulmonary atresia, right pulmonary artery reconstruction after surgery, in 11 years old girl. Results 64 detectors CT revealed right sided arcus aorta, dilatation of the ascending aorta, left pulmonary atresia, reconstruction of the right pulmonary artery, dilatation of the right atrium and ventricle in patient followed up with the diagnosis of tetralogy of fallot. We represented multiplanar reformatted and three dimentional images of this patient. Conclusion 64 detectors CT imaging modality has an important contrubution for detailed imaging of the tetralogy of fallot disease with the help of MPR and three dimentional images. volume rendering methods, images of 2 or 3 dimensions on different planes were developed. Results Based on these images, congenital aorta and vena cava anomalies and accompanying anatomic variations were clearly observed. With its volumetric imaging quality, MDCT angiography demonstrates the aorta, vena cava, and pulmonary artery and their branches. Conclusion The main diagnostic method for detection of vascular structuries is conventional angiography. Because of recent advances in CT technology, MDCT angiography has replaced conventional angiography in most clinical applications. MDCT angiography is a relatively new method and it is very useful in the diagnosis and management of congenital aorta and vena cava anomalies.
Tetralogy of Fallot with left pulmonary artery agenesis and a right-sided aortic arch: 16-slice CT findings Nilgun Isiksalan Ozbulbul Radiology, Turkiye Yuksek Ihtisas Hospital

Background Congenital absence of one pulmonary artery is a rare entity. It may occur as an isolated lesion or in combination with other cardiac or vascular lesions. Less than 2% of patients have the aortic arch on the same side as the absent pulmonary artery. The most frequently associated anomalies include tetralogy of Fallot or septal defects. The blood supply to the affected lung is achieved via bronchial arteries, MAPCAs, and other systemic arteries, such as intercostal and transpleural vessels. Patients with tetralogy of Fallot and unilateral absence of a pulmonary artery are a high-risk group for whom there is no consensus on the correct approach to medical management.Multidetector technology provides important information with high accuracy and specifity for anatomic details of congenital heart disease for the referring cardiologist. Objective We present the MDCT angiography findings of a 14-yearold girl who have tetralogy of Fallot with left pulmonary artery agenesis and a right-sided aortic arch. Materials and methods We performed thorax CT angiography with a 16-slice CT scanner (Lightspeed 16, GE, Wis) . Results MDCT study demonstrated unilateral left pulmonary artery agenesis. Also, elevation of the hemidiaphragm on the affected side, ipsilateral small hilum, and ipsilateral mediastinal shift were seen. CT scan confirmed the large VSD, right ventricular outflow obstruction, right ventricular hypertrophy and aortic over-ride. In addition, a rightsided aortic arch was present. Large aortopulmonary collateral arteries (MAPCAs) were identified arising from descendan aorta. No associated coronary anomaly was detected. Conclusion MDCT angiography is a good diagnostic modality for use in the evaluation of the congenital heart disease.

Vascular rings in children: CT evaluation and 3-D image superimposition Chao Jan Wang, Wan Chak Lo Chang Gung Children's Hospital Background Vascular compression on the airway in children is usually caused by the congenital anomalies of great vessels. The most common congenital anomalies associated with airway compression are the vascular rings. The emergence of multidetector row computed tomography (MDCT) and the advance of post-processing technology have revolutionized the imaging presentation of the congenital anomalies of pediatric airway and vascular rings. Objective To evaluate the great vessels and the tracheobronchial tree in children with congenital vascular ring by using MDCT and three dimensional image reconstruction and superimposition. Materials and methods From January 2006 to October 2008, eighteen children, 10 male and 8 female, age ranging from 1 month to 12 years, undertook CT examination under the impression of upper airway obstruction with possible vascular compression due to vascular ring. Sixteen or sixty-four slice CT scanners were used for volumetric dataset. Then all the sub-millimeter thin-slice reconstructed axial images were processed on a workstation. Multiplanar display and three-dimensional images were accomplished in every case, focusing on the relationship of the great vessels and the tracheobronchial tree. Results Vascular rings including double aortic arch, pulmonary artery sling, right-side aortic arch with Kommerell diverticulum and left-side aortic arch with aberrant right subclavian artery were demonstrated. Extrinsic airway compression of variable severity was well depicted by the three-dimensional superimposition images of the great vessels and the tracheobronchial tree. All had bronchoscopic correlation and some were surgically confirmed. Conclusion Imaging plays a crucial role in the diagnosis and treatment of vascular compression of the airway in children. With the advances of MDCT technology and 3D volume rendering capability, it can offer precise anatomy required for surgical planning and it may replace barium swallow, magnetic resonance and conventional angiography while dealing with cases of vascular rings.
CT features of mediastinal lymphangiohemangioma with pericardial invasion in a 6-year-old boy Siu-Cheung Chan, C Hsueh, K-K Ng Chang Gung Memorial Hospital, Keelung, Taiwan

Background Discuss the CT manifestation of mediastinal lymphangiohemangioma with pericardial invasion in the 6-year-old boy. Case report We report a case of huge cystic anterior mediastinal mass in a 6-year-old boy with progressive substernal pain. Enhanced CT scan revealed a huge anterior mediastinal mass with homogeneous enhancement and mass effect which displaced the heart posteriorly. A histological diagnosis of lymphangiohemangioma with pericardial invasion was obtained by radical mass excision and partial pericardiectomy. Discussion Mediastinal lymphangiohemangioma, a rare hybrid tumor composed of both vascular and lymphatic components, is a rare primary mesenchymal tumor. CT is useful in the diagnosis of mediastinal lymphangiiohemangioma due to intense contrast enhancement of the intratumoral vascular spaces. Different types of enhanced patterns in CT scan, including focal areas of homogeneous, inhomogeneous enhancement or, lack of contrast enhancement were reported, and they were believed due to varying vascularity of the lesions. Although the definitive diagnosis of lymphangiohemangioma depends on histopathology, lymphangiohemangioma should be suspected in a case of a mediastinal mass with different components including well-enhanced vascular spaces and cystic appearing areas. CT is helpful to assess the extension of the tumor and the possible associated complications.

Massive pulmonary ossification due to recurrent aspiration pneumonia Bilal Battal 1 , Murat Kocaoglu 2 , Fatih Ors 2 , Sabahattin Vurucu 3 1. Radiology, Sarikamis Military Hospital, Kars, Turkey 2. Radiology, Gulhane Military Medical School, Ankara, Turkey 3. Pediatric Neurology, Gulhane Military Medical School, Ankara, Turkey

Background Pulmonary ossification (PO) is an idiopathic disorder and presents with the formation of mature bone in the pulmonary parenchyma. This entity has been reported in a number of diseases such as chronic bronchitis, busulfan therapy, cystic fibrosis, congestive heart failure, myositis ossificans and idiopathic interstitial fibrosis, and usually seen in older age groups. We present a child with PO due to recurrent aspiration pneumonia. Objective To present clinical and imaging findings of a 4-year-old male with massive PO secondary to recurrent aspiration pneumonia. Materials and methods A 4-year-old male who had mental and motor retardation, epilepsy, dysfunctioning epiglottis and recurrent aspiration pneumonia was evaluated by chest radiography, high resolution computed tomography (HRCT) and cranial magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). Results On physical examination bilateral rales were detected. Hematological tests and sputum culture were unremarkable. Hypercapnia and hypoxemia were present. A cranial MRI, which was obtained for assessing epilepsy showed cerebral atrophy. The chest radiography revealed bilateral reticulonodular pulmonary infiltrates, patchy consolidation and pneumonic infiltrates resembling organizing pneumonia. Bilateral patchy radioopacities consistent with calcification were also noted. HRCT showed bilateral subpleural or peribronchial areas of consolidation associated with massive ossification. Conclusion Recurrent aspiration pneumonia may result in extensive PO in children; however, more cases are necessary to be able to conclude whether this finding has prognostic and therapeutic implications. Background A wide spectrum of congenital abnormalities of the aortic arch and its branches can occur due to the failure of fusion or regression of the vascular arches. These abnormalities can cause symptoms of like stridor, dyspnoea, dysphagia and cyanosis due to the compression of trachea or oesophagus. Objective To review the normal embryology of the aortic arch. To provide a pictorial review of the various types of congenital vascular ring anomalies.

Materials and methods Our exhibit demonstrates aortic arch and other types of vascular ring anomalies using a combination of imaging modalities including chest x-ray, barium oesophagography and MDCT. We will illustrate the vascular anatomy and its effects on the adjacent oesophagus/tracheobronchial tree using cross sectional imaging, MIP, multiplanar reformats (MPR) and volume reconstruction. Results We will classify and depict the different types of aortic arch anomalies using Edwards's classification: Group 1: Double aortic arches-both arches patent, one arch atresia Group 2: Left aortic arches-normal branching, aberrant subclavian Group 3: Right aortic arches-mirror branching, aberrant subclavian We will also demonstrate some other types of vascular rings. Conclusion It is crucial for pediatric radiologist to be familiarized with the anatomical variants and findings of the various aortic arch anomalies. The diagnosis of the surgical significant vascular tracheoesophageal compressive syndrome (VTECS) will allow for prompt and timely interventional when required. The proper use of imaging algorithm will avoid unnecessary investigation or radiation.

Pain chest X-ray: A reliable tool for the evaluation of pediatric patients with pneumonia E Fitsiou 1 , I Tiliakos 1 , V Ouranos 2 , H Moschouris 2 , MG Papadaki 2 1. Department of Pediatric, Tzanio Piraeus Hospital, Greece 2. Department of Radiology, Tzanio Piraeus Hospital, Greece

Background Pediatric patients with pneumonia may present symptoms of variable gravity. CRX required to confirm clinical signs and also to verify recovery. Objective Our aim is to highlight the role of CXR in diagnosis and follow-up of children with pneumonia. Materials and methods In a six month period, 47 children with pneumonia, aged 30 days to14 years, (median age 4,5 years) were hospitalized in our department. We recorded the clinical severity and the duration of symptoms and we correlated them with CXR findings. All children had at least one CXR upon admission. Recurring CXRs were obtained according to clinical criteria. Results 14 children (30%) were admitted the day symptoms appeared, 29 children (62%) 2-5 days later, while 4(8%) had symptoms for more than 5 days before hospitalization. Tweenty children (42,5%) presented severe symptoms and admission CRX demonstrated lobar (4/20) or segmental consolidation (16/20). 27 patients (57,5%) with segmental consolidation presented minor clinical symptoms. Thirty-four children (72%) had a recurring CXR during hospitalization. Most of the 2nd CXRs (74%) were obtained on the 4th-8th day of hospitalization, and only one case did not reveal improvement. CXRs obtained before the 4th day of hospitalization showed no improvement in 4 out of 5 patients. The majority of patients (89%) showed signs of recovery between the 2nd and 4th day of hospitalization. Recovery was confirmed with a 2nd CXR for 29 patients (91%) while in 3, 2nd CXR did not reveal signs of improvement. CXR of patients with persistent symptoms confirmed stability. 3rd CXR was obtained in only 3 children with continuing signs of pneumonia or complications(empyema). Conclusion Plain chest x-ray is a reliable tool for the evaluation of pediatric patients with pneumonia. Upon admission, CRX findings reliably confirm severity of clinical signs. In the majority of cases a 2nd CXR, confirms recovery when performed on the 4th-8th day of hospitalization. A 3rd CXR is necessary when complications are encountered.

Pictorial review of central airway anomalies / abnormalities in pediatric patients with underlying congenital heart disease: 64 MDCT evaluation with emphasis on 2D and 3D imaging appearance Sanjay P Prabhu, Edward Y Lee Children's Hospital Boston

Background In recent years, multidetector CT (MDCT) has become an essential noninvasive imaging tool for evaluating central airway anomalies / abnormalities in children with underlying congenital heart disease.

Objective The goal of this pictorial exhibit is to review: 1) the most updated 64 MDCT techniques for evaluating central airways; and 2) MDCT imaging appearance of central airway anomalies / abnormalities in children with underlying congenital lung disease with an emphasis on 2D and 3D imaging appearances. Materials and methods We retrospectively reviewed 64 MDCT studies performed in children (< 18 years old) who underwent MDCT studies for evaluation of underlying intra and extracardiac congenital heart disease from July 2004 to December 2008 at our institution. Pediatric patient preparation, MDCT scanning parameters with emphasis on low radiation dose technique, and 2D/3D postprocessing reconstruction techniques were investigated in detail. Cases with central airway anomalies / abnormalities were collected and illustrative cases with particular emphasis on their 2D and 3D imaging appearances are presented. Results A wide spectrum of concomitant central airway anomalies / abnormalities was identified in pediatric patients with underlying congenital heart disease. Intrinsic central airway anomalies / abnormalities include tracheal stenosis, anomalous bronchial branching pattern (e.g., tracheal bronchus, cardiac bronchus) and tracheobronchomalacia. Extrinsic central airway anomalies / abnormalities include vascular rings and sling, as well as extrinsic central airway compression secondary to adjacent dilated pulmonary vessels, abnormal position of the aorta, and cardiomegaly. Conclusion The advent of 64 Slice MDCT has played a major role as a non-invasive imaging tool for evaluating central airway anomalies / abnormalities in pediatric patients with underlying congenital heart disease. Understanding updated 64 MDCT techniques and characteristic imaging appearances of central airway anomalies/abnormalities in these children will lead to optimal patient management by providing essential preoperative information of both underlying congenital heart disease and associated central airway anomalies / abnormalities.

Thoracic manifestations of systemic diseases, radiological approach Pilar Garcia-Peña, Ignasi Barber, Helena Boixadera, Nuria Toran, Javier Lucaya, Goya Enriquez Hospital Materno-Infantil Vall d´Hebron, Barcelona, Spain Background This work will present our experience in the evaluation of the chest in children with systemic diseases during the last six years in our institution. Objective The purpose of this presentation is to review the role of thoracic imaging in children with systemic disorders. Examination techniques and specific systemic conditions with thoracic manifestations will be discussed. Materials and methods During the last 6 years we review 3,000 patients with systemic disease. The most frequent radiological examination techniques were Chest X-ray/CR, Computed Tomography and Nuclear medicine, following by MRI in some cases. Low-dose techniques have been applied to both helical CT and high-resolution CT (HRCT). Results Plain radiographs/CR remain the fist most common thoracic imaging study. Computed tomography (CT) is the primary crosssectional imaging modality used to evaluate all thoracic components due to its increased sensitivity and specificity compared to chest radiography. CT may be used either to better evaluate radiographic abnormalities or to assess the presence and extent of a suspected systemic disease. HRCT is the method of choice for the evaluation of diffuse parenchymal disease. Evaluation of the mediastinum and chest wall should be performed with helical CT. MRI is better in evaluating the chest wall or in demonstrating soft tissue inflammation and rib bone marrow changes compared to CT. Nuclear medicine can add functional information to the morphological information provided by CT and MRI.The systemic diseases in children includes the connective tissue diseases, immunodeficiency and immunodeficiency syndromes, chronic granulomatous disease, Langerhans´s cell histiocitosis, cystic fibrosis, immotile cilia syndrome, vasculitis, etc. Conclusion Chest radiograph underestimates the detection and extent of lung disease in systemic diseases. HRCT detect, characterize and determine the extent of the interstitial and alveolar disease. Early recognition of disease will lead to prompt treatment that can be beneficial in preventing and improving progression of the disease. Objective To describe CT findings of a rare venous anomaly and tracheal stenosis in a newborn baby. Materials and methods A baby boy was born at the gestational age of 39 weeks and 1 day weighing 3,104 g. He was presented with mild grunting soon after birth. The peripheral oxygen saturation (SpO2) was 84-93%, despite oxygen administration through nasal cannulae. He was mildly cyanotic, however tachypnea and retraction were not observed. Echocardiography revealed PLSVC, atrial septal defect or persistent foramen ovale. No other cardiac anomaly could be obtained. No abnormal findings were demonstrated on chest radiograph. However SpO2 did not improve. For this unexplained hypoxemia, chest CT was performed on day 7. Results Enhanced CT showed PLSVC draining into LA. Right SVC was absent. This venous anomaly leads to right-to-left shunt, and accounts for hypoxemia. Contrast echocardiography confirmed this anomaly. He underwent surgical treatment which was successful. At the age of nine months, recurrent stridor occurred. Tracheal stenosis was revealed on CT. Conclusion We report the newborn baby with PLSVC draining into LA with absent right SVC and associated tracheal stenosis diagnosed by enhanced CT. CT clearly demonstrated this rare congenital systemic venous anomaly, and was very useful in the initial evaluation of unexplained hypoxemia.

Prenatal and postnatal assessment of VACTERL association radiographics findings Marianna Tagliabue, Dorothy Bulas, Rhonda Schonberg, Kenneth Rosenbaum Ospedale S Gerardo, Monza, Italy, Children National Medical Center, Washington DC, USA Background VACTERL is an acronym describing the concurrence of specific, nonrandom congenital anomalies of unknown etiology including Vertebral, Anal atresia, Cardiac, Tracheo-Esophageal fistula, Renal and Limb anomalies. The diagnosis may be difficult to establish with numerous associated anomalies that can resemble or overlap other pathologic conditions. Some anomalies may be too subtle to recognize prenatally. Successful postnatal radiologic assessment requires an understanding of the complexities of these various anomalies. Objective In light of the numerous anomalies and variable prognosis of VACTERL association, timely and accurate diagnosis for appropriate management and follow-up is important. The prenatal and postnatal radiologic evaluation of VACTERL association will be presented. Materials and methods Retrospective review of prenatal and postnatal imaging findings in patients with VACTERL association from January 1998 July 2008 was performed. Prenatal evaluation by US and MRI as well as postnatal evaluation by X-ray, fluoroscopy, CT, US, MRI and nuclear medicine was reviewed. Results Prenatal US was particularly useful in the assessment of cardiac, renal, cleft lip and skeletal anomalies. Fetal MRI was helpful at times for the assessment of anal atresia, cranial anomalies and pulmonary agenesis. Both modalities were useful in diagnosing 2 vessel cord and duodenal atresia. Both MRI and US were limited in the assessment of TE fistula, tethered cord and some vertebral anomalies prenatally.

Postnatal radiologic evaluation included a combination of X-rays for limb, spine and bowel anomalies. Fluoroscopy was important for the assessment of TE fistula repairs, recto-vesico/urethral fistulas and renal anomalies. Radionuclide scans and US were useful for assessing renal anomalies. CT and MR were useful to evaluate pulmonary agenesis, tethered cord, vertebral anomalies, as well as urogenital and anal malformations. Conclusion Understanding the complex and, at times, subtle anomalies associated with VACTERL association allows for improved prenatal diagnosis and appropriate postnatal radiologic evaluation. Background Prenatal MRI is of special importance in supplementary diagnostics of systems difficult to approach with sonography, such as the lungs, vertebral canal or the brain.

Objective The purpose of this study is a quantitative and qualitative assessment of fetal lung disorders on MRI. Materials and methods 253 pregnant women between 17 and 41 years of age (15-39 weeks gestation) underwent MRI with 1,5 T units (GE SIGNA, Marconi Eclipse). SSFSE sequences and T2-weighted images in axial, coronal and sagittal planes have been used. Three to 5 mm section thickness was applied. Optionally additional sequences have been performed. Results Out of 261 fetuses examined 31 (12%) revealed lung abnormalities. Nine (29,0%) of them had pulmonary hypoplasia diagnosed, 8 (25,8%) left-sided congenital diaphragmatic hernia, 1 (3,2%) right-sided congenital diaphragmatic hernia, 7 (22,6%) congenital cystic adenomatoid malformation, 2 (6,5%) pulmonary sequestration and 3 (9,7%) other disorders. In 1 case (3,2%) no pulmonary lesion was described, although in the previous exam of the same fetus pulmonary sequestration was suspected. In all cases chest pathology has been first suspected on sonography. MRI additionally gave an opportunity to distinguish between congenital diaphragmatic hernia and congenital cystic adenomatoid malformation, revealed the hernia contents in the thorax and detected the site and extension of cystic lesions. Conclusion MRI offers an added diagnostic and prognostic value to the standard prenatal sonography also in the diagnostics of fetal lung pathologies.

MRI measurements of the fetal brain Alexia M Egloff, Hayder Hashim, Gilbert Vezina, Dorothy Bulas Children's National Medical Center Background MRI has been proven useful in the evaluation of the fetal CNS with improved anatomic detail compared to US. Knowledge of the normal appearance and measurements of the fetal brain are fundamental for the evaluation of these studies and helpful identifying SUBTLE abnormalities.

Objective The objective of our study is to provide measurements of various CNS structures at different gestational ages as an aid in the evaluation of the fetal brain. Materials and methods A total of 672 prenatal MRI studies were performed in our Institution between 1999 and December 2008. A retrospective evaluation of the studies that were digitally available was performed. From the MRI examinations available, we excluded studies with CNS abnormalities, multiple pregnancies, aneuploidy or specific syndromes.

Over 200 MRI studies were included in our study. Measurements in axial, coronal and sagittal planes were obtained, including the fronto-occipital diameter, cerebral and bone biparietal diameter, interhemispheric distance, length of the corpus callosum, height and anteroposterior diameter of the vermis, transverse cerebellar diameter, anteroposterior and craniocaudal interopercular distance, atrial diameter, biatrial diameter, thickness of the choroid plexus, lateral diameter of the third ventricle, anteroposterior diameter of the fourth ventricle. Results Data was collated and analyzed and different ratios were evaluated. Comparison with previously published data was performed to increase statistical significance. Results are presented in a poster format. Conclusion MRI examinations are frequently performed in the evaluation of the fetus. Knowledge of normal cranial measurements and characteristics of the developing central nervous system at various gestational ages is useful in the MRI evaluation of the fetal brain.
Prenatal diagnosis of a nasal glioma C Cellier, G Labadie, M Brasseur-Daudruy, V Grzecoryczyk, D Dehesdin Rouen University Hospital
Background Congenital midline nasal masses are rare, especially glioma.

Objective The differential diagnosis of foetal paranasal facial masses are discussed. Materials and methods We report a case of foetal nasal glioma diagnosed at 21 weeks of gestation. The glioma appeared as a hypoechoic mass, showing no internal vascularisation on the first ultrasound exam. At 35 weeks of gestation, the mass appeared slightly vascular. A foetal MRI excluded the possibility of an encephalocele by showing the absence of bone defect. At birth, the mass was adherent to deep plane and covered with telangiectatic skin. A Colour Doppler indicated a solid, well circumscribed hypoechoic mass with a flow pattern atypical of haemangioma. The Doppler spectrum showed arterial flow characterised by low-flow velocity. A MRI confirmed the absence of intracranial connections of the tumor, which appeared less hypervascular than haemangioma on post contrast sequences. The tumor was completely resected at the age of 5 months, via an extranasal approach. The histopathological diagnosis was nasal glioma. Conclusion US with Doppler analysis and MRI are fundamental to differentiate nasal glioma from encephalocele and haemangioma, and to plan the correct surgical approach.

Fetal imaging of abdominal wall defects Preeyacha Pacharn, Maria A Calvo-Garcia, Leann E Linam, Eva I Rubio, Beth Kline-Fath Cincinnati Children's Hospital, Cincinnati, USA Congenital anterior abdominal wall defects are resulting from in utero developmental abnormality. The correct prenatal diagnosis is important. It can lead to proper parental counseling and management.

Gastroschisis is a paraumbilical abdominal wall defect with evisceration of abdominal content into the amniotic cavity. The defect involves full thickness of the abdominal wall with no membrane. Freefloating bowel loops can be identified within the amniotic fluid.

Omphalocele is a midline anterior abdominal wall defect with herniation of abdominal viscera into the base of the umbilical cord. The eviscerated organs are separated from amniotic fluid by a membrane.

Pentalogy of Cantrell is a rare anomaly. The complete syndrome is characterized by two major defects: ectopia cordis and abdominal wall defect (usually omphalocele). Other three defects include disruption of the distal sternum, anterior diaphragm and diaphragmatic pericardium.

Limb-Body wall complex involves a variable group of congenital limb and body wall defects of the chest and abdomen. Abnormalities usually include a large ventral wall defect, lower limb rotational anomalies and scoliosis.
Amniotic band syndrome consists of defects that occur secondary to amniotic sac rupture. It may affect limb, face and sometimes associate with ventral wall abnormality.

Cloacal and bladder exstrophy are also uncommon. Cloacal exstrophy involves the retraction of the cloacal membrane and incomplete descent of the urorectal septum. Bladder exstrophy is caused by inappropriate retraction of the cloacal membrane with eversion of bladder mucosa.
The combination of omphalocele, exstrophy of bladder, imperforated anus and spinal deformities has been called the OEIS complex.
The final outcome of these defects is significantly affected by the presence of additional structural and/or chromosomal abnormalities.
The purpose of this illustration is to demonstrate the spectrum of findings of congenital abdominal wall defects diagnosed with prenatal MRI in correlation with postnatal findings.

MR imaging can elegantly show pelvic anatomy and pathology providing excellent information to guide management of these difficult complications.

Objective Use MR images to illustrate perineal anatomy of levator anni muscle, puborectalis muscle and and the internal and external anal sphincters. Demonstrate the course of fistula tracts and abscess collections, in particular transgression of muscle and sphincters.

Materials and methods Images where obtained from Bowel MR studies performed at BC Children's Hospital in Vancouver and Princess Margaret's Hospital in Perth. Background Prenatal diagnosis of intestinal atresia has been proved to have an impact on postnatal outcome (better planning of the delivery, surgical requirement). Such diagnosis is based on sonographic screening. MRI, however, can provide more accurate findings including dilated bowel signal intensity and the demonstration of the bowel distal to the atresia. Objective To assess the findings of fetal MRI for evaluating the level of intestinal atresia. Materials and methods The subjects comprised 24 fetuses (18-36 weeks? gestation), including esophageal atresia (n=12), gastric obstruction (n=1),duodenal atresia (n=9), jejunal atresia (n=2), leal atresia (n=1). Nine of the fetuses with esophageal atreis had multiple anomalies including other parts of the intestinal anomalies. After obtaining informed consent, the pregnant women underwent MRI, which was performed with a 1.5-T super conductive unit (Siemens Magnetom Vision or Symphony) using a phased-array coil. No premedicaion was given for the examinations. Half-Fourier singleshot turbo spin-echo, T2-weighted (T2-W) sequences and T1weighted (T1-W) fast gradient-echo sequences.T2-W and T1-W sequences were performed in sagittal, coronal, and often axial plans. Imagings were reviewed by a pediatric radiologist. The MR findings and suggested diagnoses were compared with the results of neonatal evaluation( clinical history, imaging data, intraoperative constitution, and pathologic examination). Results Esophageal atreisa type A and duodenal atreia were easy to diagnose. However MRI provided complete diagnosis of small bowel atresia, and identified the level of obstruction in 50% of cases. In multiple level of bowel atresia, only one level of obstruction was indentifined in this study. Conclusion MRI is useful for the diagnosis of intestinal atresia in fetuses. Recognition of the bowel distal to the atresia is an important diagnostic finding especially in small bowel atresia. At present, it is difficult to prenatally diagnose esophageal atresia type C.

body_text.text: Background Choledochal cysts are congenital anomalies of the bile ducts. They consist of cystic dilatations of the extrahepatic biliary tree, intrahepatic biliary radicles, or both. The classification system for choledochal cysts currently includes 5 major types (Todani et al, 1977) . Associated anomalies of the pancreatic duct, its junction with the common bile duct, and the long common channel formed by the two are common. Different imaging modalities have been used in preoperative investigation. The preferred techniques are US and MRI (MRCP) because they are non-invasive and do not use ionizing radiation.

body_text.text: Objective The aim of the study was to review the preoperative imaging with different modalities in different choledochal cyst types. Materials and methods The literature has been reviewed for old and new classifications. A retrospective review of patients imaged with different modern techniques at our hospital was performed. The preoperative imaging findings were correlated to surgery. Results 32 children with choledochal cysts were identified. The most common types were type I and IV, visualised mainly by MRI. In one case type II was identified by surgery. In many of the older cases, before MRI was used on the routine basis, the type was not specified. The different types are demonstrated in a pictorial review, predominantly using MRI. Conclusion US is the best initial method of evaluating dilatation of the intra-and extrahepatic biliary tree while MRCP defines the anatomic characteristics of the malformation in detail without potential complications. High correlation observed between imaging findings from MRCP and surgical findings make MRCP the method of choice for the preoperative assessment of choledochal cysts and also suitable for reevaluation of the post operative follow-up.

body_text.text: Hepatic migration of an ingested sewing needle Serhat Avcu, Ozkan Unal, Ozkan Ozen, Aydın Bora Department of Radiology, Yuzuncu Yil University, Van, Turkey

Background Although foreign body ingestion is considered more frequently in children, it can be seen in all age groups. Objective The migration of an ingested foreign body into solid organs such as liver or pancreas is rarely reported. The aim of this study is to emphasize the importance of radiological imaging in a 15 year old girl with a hepatic foreign body which is diagnosed incidentally. Materials and methods The patient is evaluated with direct roentgenogram, abdominal sonography and computed tomography (CT). Results A 15 year old girl applied to emergency room with complaint of abdominal pain. Although the patient history did not reveal any ingestion of foreign body, a lineer opacity compatible with a sewing needle in right hypochondrium was observed on upright direct roentgenogram. On abdominal sonography, a lineer echogenity (sewing needle) in segment 6 of the liver was visualised with surrounding parenchymal hypoechoic areas corresponding to inflammatory changes. On following CT scan, the diagnosis of sewing needle and surrounding foci of abscesses were confirmed. Conclusion The migration of an ingested foreign body into the liver by perforating the small bowel is a rare situation. It should be kept in mind, as in our case, pediatric patients may be aware of foreign body ingestion. In such cases, the only way of diagnosis may be radiological imaging such as roentgenogram, abdominal sonography, or CT. Background It is usually a challenge for pediatric radiologists and clinicians to decide wether the patients with intussusceptions should be performed repeated air reduction or get operation directly after they were failed in the first air enema. Objective Our purpose was to assess our current air enema successful rate and to focus on finding the factors that would impact on the success of delayed, repeated air reduction for intussusceptions in children.

We performed a retrospective analysis of all intussusception cases seen at the Capital Institute of Pediatrics, Beijing, China, a tertiary pediatric hospital, from December 2007 to October 2008. Results 343 children with intussusceptions were involved in our study and all of them were performed air enema initially. Reduction rate with first air enema was 80.76% (227/343). Delayed reduction attempts were used in 49 patients (14.29%) and were successful in 61.22% (30/49). Total reduction rate was 89.5%. Furthermore, the clinical and radiological data of different group, with success of delayed attempts and failure of delayed attempts, were compared statistically. There were significant differences between the two groups in the presence of obstruction of the small intestine on plain films (P=0.049, <0.05), the initial position of the apex of the intussusception (P=0.023, <0.05), the position of the apex of intussusception at the end of first air reduction (P= 0.003, <0.01) and the position of the apex of intussusception when the pressure was released after the first reduction (P=0.005, <0.01). Conclusion Air enema associated with the use of delayed, repeated reduction attempts is an effective approach for intussusception reduction with high successful rate. Delayed, repeated reduction attempts should be considered when the intussusceptum had great activity and there was no evidence of the small intestine obstruction on plain film initially.

Crohn's disease in children-A pictorial review using a multi-modality imaging approach Kj Au-Yong, E Fanou, A Pigott, S Vessal, D Bakanilova University Hospital of North Staffordshire, UK Background Both ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease are relatively uncommon in children. In a group of approximately 100,000 children age 15 years or younger, it is estimated that approximately 2 or 3 of them will develop Crohn's disease each year. But complications secondary to Crohn's disease are more frequent.

Objective To demonstrate the role of imaging in the diagnosis of Crohn's disease and its complications using a multi-modality imaging approach. Materials and methods We will provide a pictorial spectrum of signs and complications secondary to Crohn's disease using plain radiography, ultrasound, barium studies, white cell scan, MDCT and MRI. We will also use MRI enterography with high quality multiplanar reformats and post processing images to illustrate some of the more complex cases. Results US has a 87% sensitivity in detecting abnormal bowel pattern in children and should be the first imaging investigation in children suspected with having inflammatory bowel disease. Although double contrast upper and lower GI studies have long been the standard in the evaluation of IBD, MR imaging is increasingly used to help identify and characterize pathologically altered bowel segments as well as extraluminal lesions Conclusion The radiologist should be familiar with the use of multiple imaging modalities in the investigation and diagnosis of Crohn's disease in children and young adults to help to ensure correct diagnosis and appropriate treatment..

Choledochal cysts in children Fátima Pires, Sónia Palma, Dulce Antunes, Luísa Lobo, Miroslava Goncalves, José Fonseca-Santos Hospital de Santa Maria Background Choledochal cysts are rare congenital anomalies, consisting in cystic or fusiform dilatation of the extra-hepatic and / or intra-hepatic biliary tree.
Most of the lesions (80%) are diagnosed in infancy or childhood and in only one third of the cases the classic triad of symptoms of right upper quadrant pain, abdominal mass and jaundice is present.
Possible complications include lithiasic, inflammatory and neoplasic changes of the biliary tree.

Surgery is the treatment of choice in almost all cases. Objective 1. To describe imaging features of congenital biliary cystic disease in children. 2. To outline main differential diagnostic pitfalls. 3. To emphasise the role of imaging evaluation in diagnostic and follow up orientation. Materials and methods An overview of imaging findings of choledochal cysts is presented among selected cases studied in our department. Ultrasound plays a major role, remaining the screening examination for evaluating the biliary tract. Documenting a communication between the cyst and the biliary tree can establish the diagnosis. Further evaluation can be accomplished with Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography, a non-invasive and non-irradiating technique which is able to define the presence of the cyst, to identify its type according to the Todani's classification and to evaluate possible associated complications, allowing for adequate surgical planning. Conclusion Choledochal cysts are rare. Prompt diagnosis and surgery are needed to prevent complications. Radiologists play a major role in diagnosis, surgical planning and long term follow-up due to the possibility of carcinoma developing in the intra-hepatic ducts, even after successful surgery.

Imaging in pediatric short bowel syndrome: A pictorial essay Kamaldine Oudjhane, Jorge Davila, Jeffrey Traubici Hospital for Sick Children, University of Toronto Background Short bowel syndrome is a malabsorptive state secondary to congenital anomaly or surgical resection of a significant segment of the small intestine. It bears potential for life-threatening complications, especially the parenteral nutrition-related ones. Medical management and surgical strategies for improved absorption are key factors for survival Objective To illustrate through a pictorial essay the contribution of imaging in the medical /surgical management of short bowel syndrome. Materials and methods Cases from radiology database of short bowel syndrome were reviewed from our institution during the last 8 years. Major characteristics and complications during therapy of this clinical entity are depicted through imaging features from different modalities. Results Sonography is performant in the diagnosis of complications related to parenteral nutrition including venous catheter problems or severe liver disease (steatosis, cholestasis, cirrhosis). Infectious risk is assessed best with conventional radiographs as well as cross sectional methods (US, CT). Contrast opacifications of the gastrointestinal tract (conventional as well as loopograms) are helpful in delineating the surgical anatomy of the G I tract following enteral feeding techniques ,intestinal stomies, small bowel lengthening and serial transverse enteroplasty (STEP) procedures. Conclusion The nature and length of remaining post-surgical anatomy of the small intestine condition the occurrence of complications (bowel dysmotility, malabsorption , bacterial overgrowth). The different imaging modalities can assist in the diagnosis, monitoring and management of short bowel syndrome.

Imaging findings in rare case of forme frusta choledochal cyst P Pavicevic, V Perisic, A Sretenovic, D Zivanovic, V Vukadinovic University Childrens Hospital Belgrade Background Forme fruste choledochal cyst(FFCC) is a variant of choledochal cyst assosiated with mild or no dilatation of the extrahepatic bileduct (EHBD).Pancreatico-biliary malunion (PBMU) was found to coexist with FFCC.These rare type of anomaly in infants and children may lead to the development of malignancy of the bile duct in later life. Objective The aim of these study was to present a case of these rare condition and to show imaging findings of echosonography, CT and intraoperative cholangiography. Materials and method we are presenting a case of a 17 month-old female,with reccurent abdominal pain, fever assosiated with elevated serum liver laboratory findings as presenting syptoms. Results Echosonography which was several time repeted showed mild variabile dilatation of the extrahepatic biliary duct ( EHPD)of 6-8 mm.Longitudinal sonograms revealed in EHBD intraluminal hiperechoic ring like formation which suggested PBMU. CT and intraopeartive cholangiography confirmed the diagnosis of long common pancreatico-biliary duct, with mild dilatation of extra and intrahepatic BD .The common bile duct and gallbladder were remowed. A hepaticojejunostomy was established with Roux-en -Y reconstruction., and HP of the exiced EHBD showed chronic inlammation, with similar findings of the gallbladder.

The follow up period of 8 months was asymptomatic Conclusion Mild dilatation of EHBD(6-8 mm) on echosonography should be the leading point to the correct diagnosis of forme fruste choledochal cyst.It is important to establish the diagnosis on time, and to treate the pediatric patients surgicaly as soon as the diagnosis is made,because surgical treatment relieves symptoms and minimazes the risk of malignancy later in life.
Inflammatory pseudotumor of the liver in a child: Imaging findings P Galina, E Koskina, C Farkoni, P Karra, G Koronaios, M Zarifi "Agia Sofıa" Children Hospital, Athens, Greece

Background Inflammatory pseudotumor of the liver is a rare lesion of childhood. The radiographic appearance varies and it is difficult to make a specific diagnosis. The lesion is considered benign; but may have a fatal outcome. Objective We present the imaging findings of an inflammatory pseudotumor of the liver. Materials and methods A 7 year old boy was admitted to our hospital with a history of 2,5 year recurrent fever, every 20-30 days, of short duration 3-4 days, and with no other symptoms. During the episodes mild anemia and neutropenia were also identified. The child was referred to our depertment for sonographic evaluation of liver enlargement. Results The left liver lobe was diffusely hypoechogenic with textural disorganization and scattered microcalcifications. Intense hyperechogenic areas in the subphrenic liver surface and around the gallbladder were shown, as in fibrosis.The right lobe was enlarged with normal architecture. The left portal vein had small diameter with small vessels distally, as in cavernous transformation, possibly due to previous thrombosis. The CT scan and the abdominal MRI revealed the same findings in regard with the portal vein and moreover, multiple solid lesions along the subphrenic surface of the left liver lobe with imaging characteristics of lymph nodes. Inflammation was considered the most possible diagnosis, although the specific etiology could not be suggested. Laparotomy and microscopic examination that followed verified the inflammatory nature of the lesion. Conclusion Based on our experience with this child and according to the literature, the imaging findings of inflammatory pseudotumor are no specific and histologic examination after percutaneous biopsy or surgical procedure is necessary. However in our case the distribution of lesion, the findings of fibrosis and the absence of vessels infiltration were indicative of inflammation than tumor.

Imaging of early and late complications in pediatric orthotopic liver transplantation: A pictorial review Hassan Douis, Christophoros Nicolaou, Khalid Sharif, Helen Alton Birmingham Children's Hospital, Birmingham, UK Background Orthotopic liver transplantation is the treatment of choice in children with severe acute or chronic liver failure, for which no other therapy is available. Liver transplantation is however associated with a wide range of complications including vascular, biliary, hepatic parenchymal complications and other conditions such as lymphoproliferative disorders. Objective In this pictorial review, we describe and illustrate the spectrum of these early and late complications of pediatric liver transplantation with a particular emphasis on the advantages and disadvantages of the different imaging modalities in the diagnosis of these complications. Materials and methods The pediatric liver transplantation database in our hospital was searched for all patients with complications after liver transplantation over a period of 7 years. Selected images of early and late complications of pediatric liver transplantation were retrieved from the electronic picture archiving and communications system (PACS). Results and conclusion Liver transplantation is the treatment of choice in pediatric patients with end-stage liver disease. Although liver transplantation in children is well established it is associated with significant complications, particularly vascular complications that may lead to graft failure unless prompt treatment is instituted. It is therefore essential for the pediatric radiologist to be familiar with the spectrum of early and late complications that can occur after liver transplantation and to be aware of their typical imaging characteristics.

Plain abdominal radiography and abdominal US in evaluation of necrotising enterocolitis TH Koronaios, P Karra, P Galina, T Georgiou, P Autia, S Dara, F Anatolitou, M Zarifi "Agia Sofia" Children's Hospital of Athens, Greece

Background Necrotizing enterocolitis is an acquired inflammatory disease of the gastrointestinal tract, secondary to a complex interaction of multiple factors, notably prematurity. Its a common acute abdominal condition in the neonatal period that results in mucosal damage, leading to intestinal ischemia and necrosis.

Objective The purpose of this study is to review the role of plain abdominal radiography and sonography in the evaluation of NEC. Materials and methods From January 2008 to June 2008, 14 neonates (eight girls and six boys) were diagnosed with NEC in the neonatal intensive care of our hospital. Five of them were premature and nine were fullterm babies. Eleven were delivered with ceasarectomy and three with normal delivery. The symptoms were abdominal distention and bloody stools. Plain abdominal radiography was performed in all patients and sonography in four of them. The timing of follow up plain abdominal radiographs and abdominal US depended of the severity of NEC. Results Plain abdominal radiography revealed bowel distension with intramural air in 8 neonates, in 1 bowel distension with intramural air and air in the portal vein. In 5 neonates the abdominal radiography was normal. Bowel wall thickness was established with sonography in 2 neonates, portal vein gas and intramural air in 1 and in 1 portal vein gas, intramural air, bowel wall thickening and intraperitoneal fluid. Plain abdominal radiography was performed before the sonography. When plain abdominal radiography was abdnormal, US was abnormal as well. Conclusion Plain Abdominal radiography is the imaging modality of choice for the assessment of NEC, while abdominal US provides direct images of the abdominal structures, particularly the bowel and the presence of fluid in the peritoneal cavity. In these series portal vein gas and intramular air did not always proved to be ominous signs as some of the neonates with these signs were treated conservatively and had a favourable outcome. Objective The aim of this study is to present, four neonates with bowel obstruction (BO) caused by GDC, to emphasize on imaging findings in different diagnostic procedures and to highlight on the role of ultrasonography (US).

The study includes four neonates with clinical symptoms of BO. In all cases diagnostic work-up started with plain abdominal films. In two patients a barium enema (BE) was performed, one of them also underwent a barium meal (BM) examination. US with high frequency convex and linear transducers was performed in all cases. Results In all patients plain film indicated that an obstruction was at the proximity of the ileocecal junction. The BE in one patient confirmed the level of the obstruction while being inconclusive in the second. This patient underwent a BM that indicated an obstruction at the ileocecal junction. In all patients US revealed well defined, unilocular cystic lesions, measuring from 1,5 to 5 cm, with an anechoic content (3/4) or containing echogenic material (1/4). They were all located in the right lower abdomen. Their wall was evaluated; three layers were identified in one patient, two layers in two cases while one presented a thickened, without distinct layers, wall. Associated findings included ileum wall thickening proximal to the lesion (1/4).The diagnosis of GDC was evocated in all cases and confirmed at surgery. Conclusion GDCs may cause BO in neonatal period. US confirms the diagnosis of BO and can show the level and the cause of obstruction. A cystic nature and a distinct layer wall are highly suggestive of GDC, however, final diagnosis is always pending on microscopic features. Barium studies are probably unnecessary and should be reserved for selected cases. Background Nutcracker phenomenon is defined as compression of the left renal vein between abdominal aorta and superior mesenteric artery (SMA). It is an uncommon event and the underlying cause is not yet known. While this phenomenon frequently presents as an asymptomatic condition, it may cause abdominal pain, proteinuria, hematuria, or flank pain. Objective Evaluation of nutcracker phenomenon based on Doppler US and magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) findings of 2 cases. Nutcracker phenomenon is diagnosed by radiologic results and laboratory tests eliminating the hematuria causes. The angle between abdominal aorta and SMA is less than 90°and consequently left renal vein is entrapped and compressed between those 2 structures. Beyond the compression level, left renal vein shows dilatation. In this condition, compressed left renal vein may cause renal venous hypertension followed by left ureteral and gonadal varices. Materials and methods The two cases, 7 and 16 year-old, were presented with left flank pain. There was no clinical indication of urinary tract infection. Proteinuria and microscopic hematuria were detected in the urinalysis. CBC, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, Creactive protein, coagulation profile, and selective urine cytology were normal. Renal US, renal Doppler US, and MRA studies were performed. Results Renal US revealed normal sized left kidney and distinct cortex-medulla boundary. No nephrocalcinosis was found. Doppler US and MRA studies showed superior mesenteric artery as seperating from abdominal aorta by a considerably acute angle in both of the cases. Consequently, left renal vein was appearing to be compressed between abdominal aorta and superior mesenteric artery while demonstrating a dilatation after that point. Diagnosis was established based on the clinical, laboratory, and radiologic results. Conclusion Nutcracker phenomenon should be considered following elimination of other differential diagnoses in cases presenting with nonspecific abdominal pain alongside proteinuria and hematuria for which Doppler US and MRA provide supportive findings.

Choosing the right diagnostic method in gastroesophageal reflux disease? Are the pediatricians aware of the radiation exposure? Cigdem Uner, Secil Eksioglu, Yasemin Tasci Yildiz Dr Sami Ulus Cocuk Hastanesi, Ankara, Turkey

Background In most patients gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is a clinical diagnosis. Pediatricians require an objective test. Fluoroscophy and technetium sulfur colloid scintigraphy are some of the diagnostic imaging tests but the risk of exposure should be considered. Objective Learning which imaging method is superior in diagnosing GERD and increasing awareness of the radiation exposure. Materials and methods 123 pediatricians are inquired on radiation exposure during diagnostic tests for GERD. Results Of the 250 inquiry forms, 123 were answered. Conclusion 74% of the participants stated that the degree of radiation exposure is more during flouroscophic examinations than scintigraphic examinations. Eighty-six percent of the participants stated that scintigraphic examinations were superior in diagnosing the reflux disease. The ones who stated that the radiation exposure was equel in both methods were less than 0.1%

Evolution of renal cell carcinoma in a 16-year-old adolescent: CT findings Shin-Lin Shih, Yu-Peng Liu, Yi-Fang Chen, Fei-Shih Yang Department of Radiology, Mackay Memorial Hospital A 16-year-old man presented with painless hematuria. The physical examination and past history were non-contributory. CT scan of the abdomen revealed a 3; 3 cm high-attenuation mass in the lower pole of left kidney in precontrast images, which showed heterogeneous enhancement in postcontrast images. Biopsy of the lesion was taken, and the pathologic diagnosis was reactive atypia. Follow-up CT study 7 months later showed interval growth of the mass to 3.5; 3.5 cm with a tiny calcification and enlarged enhancing soft tissue part. Rebiopsy of the lesion was done and revealed interstitial fibrosis. Another follow-up CT scan was performed 15 months later and showed minimal enlargement of the mass to 3.6; 3.5 cm with stippled calcifications in the periphery and further enlargement of the irregularly enhancing soft tissue part as compared with last study. The pathologic diagnosis after partial left nephrectomy was type 2 papillary renal cell carcinoma. The patient was doing well 7 months after operation. We present the serial images to show the chronological evolution of the tumor on CT. Background The hydrocele of the canal of Nuck is very rare condition in female. So its radiologic finding is rarely reported. Objective To introduce the characteristic ultrasonographic finding, named as gooseneck sign, of hydrocele of the canal of Nuck in pediatric patients Materials and methods 2 young childrens (22 months, 14 months old females. respectively) were presented with irreducible inguinal palpable mass. All two cases were located at the right side. Ultrasound of the right inguinal area was performed with a 5-12 Mhz linear array transducer.. Results An well circumscribed unilocular cystic mass with a waist and its tail directed cranially to the inguinal canal was revealed on ultrasound examination, showing the gooseneck appearance, in all cases. Conclusion This ultrasonographic typical finding is helpful to diagnose the hydrocele of the canal of Nuck that is rare disease in female.

A giant multicystic dysplastic kidney: Prenatal US and MRI findings Ibrahim Adaletli, Sebuh Kurugoglu, Onur Tutar, Riza Madazli, Cenk Buyukunal Istanbul University Cerrahpasa Medical School, Turkey Background The multicystic dysplastic kidney is a relatively common form of renal pathology. The multicystic dysplastic kidney can be unilateral, bilateral or segmental and probably results from atresia of the ureteral bud system during embryogenesis. We present the prenatal MRI and US findings of an atypical and giant multicystic dysplastic kidney. A 37-year-old woman, gravida 3, parity 2, underwent prenatal sonography examination at the 24 week's gestation. The size, contour and texture of the right kidney were normal on sonography. However, on the left side, a giant multilocular and multiseptated cystic lesion was detected. The lesion occupied the left kidney location also extended up to the diaphragm in the cranial direction. No kidney parenchyma was observed inside the lesion. The initial interpretation of the perinatologist was multicystic dysplastic kidney. For these findings to be evaluated further and to be validated, prenatal MRI was performed at 25 week's of gestation. The mother was in a supine position for the examination, and the images were acquired during maximal inspiration. The fetal urogenital system was examined in sagittal, transverse, and coronal orientations using a T2weighted sequence (HASTE; TR/TE, 1,380/103; field of view, 250 mm; slice thickness, 4 mm; matrix, 256×256; number of excitations, 1). In MR images, the left kidney could not be identified. A giant multilocular and multiseptated cystic lesion was detected on the left side.The size and contour of the right kidney was normal. MRI findings of the cystic mass suggested multicystic dysplastic kidney and cystic lymphangioma. There were no accompanying congenital anomalies.
Adrenal haemorrhage presenting as acute scrotal swelling in a neonate: A case report V Bolli, G Pieroni, C Lanza, L Amici, VC Noviello, G Fabrizzi Azienda Ospedaliero-Universitaria Ospedali Riuniti
Background Neonatal adrenal hemorrhage occurs in 0.2% of newborns because of a birth trauma, hypoxia or spontaneously and may rarely present as scrotal hematoma.

Objective We present a case report of newborn with right adrenal hemorrage presenting as left scrotal hematoma. Materials and methods A male born after 38 weeks gestation after normal first pregnancy and vaginal delivery in premature rupture of membranes (PROM), presented with edema, thickness and purplish discolouration of the left hemiscrotum; the testis was mobile and the right side scrotal skin normal. Results Ultrasonography (US) showed scrotal soft tissue edema and difficoult identification of the vascularization. For the clinical suspicion of testicular torsion was performed a left surgical exploration that excluded complicated hernia and testicular torsion but a large scrotal hematoma extending until the groin was found with blood within the spermatic cord and tunica vaginalis. Postoperative abdominal US showed a right suprarenal mass hemorrhage (39× 25 mm) without peritoneal or retroperitoneal blood collection. US 3months follow up (once a month) showed a gradual decresing of the adrenal hematoma. Conclusion Adrenal hemorrhage is generally associated with perinatal hypoxia but spontaneous occurrence is nor rare. The right side is more often involved. Clinical presentation is various, depending on the volume of blood coming out. If the blood goes down into the retroperitoneal space it can descend into the groin and presenting as a scrotal swelling. Although the adrenal hemmorrhage is a condition relatively common in newborn, only 20 cases with scrotal hematoma have been described so far and to our knowledge this is the first case with controlateral scrotal hematoma prentation. Adrenal haemorrhage should be considered as a possible cause of acute scrotal swelling in neonates. Ultrasonography assessment should be performed to examine the intra-abdominal organs especially the adrenal glands, to find out an adrenal hemmorrhage and avoid an unnecessary scrotal surgical exploration.
Ultrasound of cystic dysplasia of the testis in two boys Živa Zupančič, Senja Mali Brajovič, Bojan Tršinar University Medical Center Ljubljana, Slovenia

Background In suspected testicular pathology of an enlarged testis accurate assessment by high-resolution ultrasound with flow Doppler (US) is essential. When a pathologic change of the testis is detected, it is important, if possible, to make a correct diagnosis in order to enable an appropriate treatment decision. Objective In children, testicular enlargement can be caused by cyctic dysplasia of the testis (CDT), a rare congenital condition. As CDT has a rather characteristic US appearance and can be diagnosed by US only, we decided to present US findings in two cases to help in recognising this entity, and to report on treatment decisions. Materials and methods Two boys, a 2-month-old infant and a 2-yearold boy, with slight unilateral testicular enlargement were investigated by high resolution US and with flow Doppler of the testes, and by abdominal US. Results In both boys, US of the affected testis demonstrated enlargement and pathologic testicular structure, in the infant located dorsally, occupying half of the testis, in the boy in the central region, occupying less than half of the testis. The pathologic structures were rather well defined and consisted of multiple, small, anechoic, cystic structures with lack of flow signal. The diagnosis was CDT in both boys. Abdominal US of the 2-year-boy revealed ipsilateral renal agenesis. The infant had surgery with partial resection of the testis; the diagnosis of CDT was conformed. For the older boy it was decided to do follow up by US only. Conclusion Testicular enlargement can be caused by CDT, a rare congenital condition, which can be associated with ipsilateral renal agenesis or dysplasia. It has a rather specific US appearance with no flow signal and can thus be correctly diagnosed by high resolution US with Doppler flow. The diagnosis enables a correct treatment decision. Background To present similar two cases of testicular fibrosis due to undiagnosed testicular torsion. The first case was a12-year-old male, who was referred to our sonography division for small testis suspicious. In ultrasound(US) left testis was small and tunica albuginea was thick and hyperechogenic. After orchiectomia, histopathologic exam revealed ischemic necrosis and fibrosis, consistent with testicular torsion The second case was a 13-years-old male; he underwent US study two weeks after scrotal pain and swelling. First US study showed heterogenous epididymis and testis on the right side without focal mass. Repeated US scan two months after the symptoms showed hyperechogenic tunica albuginea suggesting fibrosis similar to first case Both cases were showing decreased testicular dimension and hyperechogenic, thick tunica albuginea resembling calcification. But the x-ray graphies did not confirm calcification.Tunica albuginea fibrosis and small testis can be a sequel of subclinic testicular torsion.

Testicular microlithiasis in children: Role of imaging and literature review Paolo MS Schingo, Cinzia Orazi, Antonio Spagnoli, Fabio Ferro, Massimiliano Silveri Bambino Gesù Childrens' Hospital Rome Italy Background In the pediatric age group testicular microlithiasis is a rare disease, characterized by diffuse, intratesticular non-shadowing echogenic small foci. It mostly represents an incidental finding during routine scrotal sonography, but it can be associated with several conditions, such as cryptorchidism, gonadal dysgenesis and alveolar microlithiasis. The coexistence of testicular germ cell tumors and the occurrence of malignant processes have raised the suspicion of being a premalignant lesion in adults. Objective To assess the typical sonographic appearance of this condition and its significance. Materials and methods Between 2001 and 2008 we detected testicular microlithiasis in 20 patients, ranging from 18 months to 18 years of age (average 9 years). The patients were followed up annually.

Results The actual cause of testicular microlithiasis is still unknown. It is believed to result from multiple calcium microprecipitates inside the seminiferous tubules. We found the typical sonographic pattern with variably extending multiple parenchymal non-shadowing echogenic small foci, evenly distributed or in peripheral clusters. Sonographic follow-up did not put into evidence the onset of neoplasms in our series. Also tumoral markers (CEA, beta HCG, alfa-feto protein) were within normal ranges. Conclusion Testicular microlithiasis, variably involving the parenchyma, can easily be recognized on US examination. Although no tumoral lesions have been detected in our pediatric series, in accordance with literature data, some aspects still need further investigation and larger population and longer control periods might be necessary. Objective The aim of this study was to estimate the correlation between mean normalized apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC) values and split renal functions determined by renal scintigraphy. Materials and methods This retrospective study included 20 children (12 male, 8 female, age range 10 months-13 years) with suspected obstructive uropathy. All patients underwent an MR examination on one of two different 1.5-T systems. We measured the renal parenchymal and paraspinal muscle ADC values and correlate mean normalized ADC values with split renal functions. We used Mann-Whitney U Test for statistical analysis. Results We found that the mean normalized ADC values of normal functioning kidneys in the same individual were similar. On the other hand, the differences between mean normalized ADC values of each kidney, in the same individual with functionally differing kidneys, were statistically significant (p<0.001). Conclusion These results indicated that measurement of mean normalized ADC has a potential value in the evaluation of the functional status of renal parenchyma.

Vertical inversion of the testis: Sonographic recognition of a possible malposition of the gonad Cinzia Orazi, Antonio Spagnoli, Paolo MS Schingo, Fabio Ferro Bambino Gesù Children's Hospital, Rome, Italy

Background Vertical inversion of the testis is a rare malposition of the gonad. It is mostly an occasional finding, which can be recognized for the caudal position of the epididymal head. No changes of the gonadal volume and echotexture are expected. Objective To assess the role of ultrasonography in the identification of this uncommon gonadal malposition. Materials and methods We describe sonographic and color-Doppler findings in 4 patients, ranging from 16 to 18 years of age, complaining about some recurrent scrotal troubles, exacerbating during intense physical activity. On physical examination the testes presented normal volume, consistency and mobility, and the cremasteric reflex was present. Results Sonography confirmed normal-sized, symmetrical testes, with homogeneous parenchymal echotexture. Color-Doppler demonstrated normal intraparenchymal flow. However, the left testis had a peculiar malposition with the epididymal head lying at the bottom of the scrotal sac, and the epididymal tail, with the spermatic vessels, at the top. Because of the vertical inversion of the testis, spermatic vessels were somewhat stretched, but flow was preserved. Low grade varicocele and a small amount of hydrocele were present in 2 out of 4 patients. Conclusion Testicular malposition could be brought on by the absence of the scrotal ligament, due to a developmental anomaly of the gubernaculum testis, which is responsible for gonadal fixation at the bottom of the scrotal sac. Moreover, also a mesorchium relaxation could be responsible for an excessive mobility of the testis in the scrotum, while a greater length of the spermatic cord avoiding a severe kinking of the vessels, could warrant blood supply to the gonad. Two of our patients underwent corrective surgery with normal repositioning of the testis, which was then fixed at the bottom of the scrotum. Sonographic recognition of this anomaly is rather simple and may be an occasional finding, although the abnormal epididymal position could be clinically suspected, on the basis of a correct anamnesis.

Unilateral urinoma and anterior urethral obstruction from syringocele in a newborn: Role of imaging Cinzia Orazi, Massimiliano Silveri, Fausto M Fassari, Paolo MS Schingo Bambino Gesù Children' Hospital Rome, Italy

Background In fetal and neonatal period urinoma is due to urinary extravasation, through ruptured caliceal fornices. Both urinoma and urinary ascites can be associated with obstructed urinary outflow, such as ureteropelvic junction obstruction and neonatal posterior urethral valves and are related with protected fetal and neonatal renal function, thanks to the so called "pop-off" valve mechanism, that prevents high intravesical pressures with transmittance to the upper urinary tract, which is an hypothesized cause of the development of renal insufficiency. Objective To assess the role of imaging in the recognition of this uncommon urethral obstruction. Materials and methods We report the case of a 2-month-old baby with unremarkable prenatal diagnosis, presenting with sudden onset of febrile urinary tract infection, macroscopic haematuria, and failure to thrive. No reports on micturition characters are given. Results Abdominal sonography revealed a voluminous subcapsular septated collection surrounding the left kidney, which showed a deep scar in the outer surface, widely communicating with the external collection. Bladder wall were slightly thickened. MRI confirmed the extrarenal collection, with fluid presenting intermediate characteristics between urine and blood. Voiding cystourethrography demonstrated the caliceal leak of contrast in the subcapsular and perirenal space. The syringocele appeared as a sort of diverticulum of the bulbar urethra, filling with contrast during the incomplete micturition, bladder only slightly emptying. Conclusion Syringocele represents a congenital or acquired dilatation of Cowper's ducts. Cowper's bulbo-urethral glands, homologous to Bartolini's glands in females, are located between the layers of the urogenital diaphragm and in the spongiosus body, along the bulbar urethra, and their ducts open directly into the urethra. Syringocele may cause hydronephrosis in utero. In the newborn there may be severe obstruction, often followed by renal function deterioration, as in presence of posterior urethral valves. In our case, the "pop-off" mechanism related with the perirenal urinoma guaranteed decompression of the upper urinary tract and preservation of renal function. Endoscopic and/or surgical treatment allows restoration of the normal anatomy.
Technique and applications of CT urography in pediatric population Kamil Gurel, Safiye Gurel, Erdal Karavas Abant Izzet Baysal University, Bolu, Turkey

Background CT urography has become the most popular method in the evaluation of urinary system pathologies in adult population in the last decade. The use of CT urography in pediatric population still has not been that much familiar to most radiologists and clinicans. Objective Our aim is to describe CT urography (CTU) technique with its basic principles and modifications for pediatric age group, discuss advantages and disadvantages of the technique and to demonstrate various examples from different age groups of pediatric population. Materials and methods Between May 2003 and December 2008, 25 patients referred for CT urography to radiology department were included. CTU protocole consists of non-contrast (precontrast (3 mm slice thickness); nephrographic (scanned at 80 s with 10 mm slice thickness) and excretion phases (scanned at 15 min. with 3 mm slice thickness) which were modified depending on the clinical information to avoid excessive radiation risk. Whole urinary system (kidneyureter-bladder) were included in non-contrast and excretion phases while only kidneys are included for the nephrographic phase. Results Uni-/bilateral ureteropelvic junction stenosis (n=5), nonfunctioning kidney (n=1), nephrolithiasis (n=6), ureterolithiasis (n=3), ectopic kidney (n=1), double collecting system (n=2), hypoplastic kidney with extrarenal pelvis (n=1), pelvicalyceal dilatation (n=4), renal agenesis (n=1), sacral agenesis (n=1) were detected. Conclusion The main principle for pediatric CTU should be 'every case needs individual care and modification of the protocole'. In diagnosis of some complex urologic problems CTU may be necessary in pediatric patients. Selection of patients with appropriate indications, cautious determination of CT parameters considering benefit/ cost in terms of radiation, make it a practical diagnostic tool with all facilites of cross-sectional imaging in pediatric population.
Ultrasonografic evaluation of ureteral stones in pediatric patients Umit Yasar Ayaz Ministry of Health Mersin Pediatrics Hospital, Mersin, Turkey
Background Ureteral stone disease in pediatric patients require prompt diagnosis to exclude other surgical emergencies and to start efficient treatment.

Objective The objective of the study is to report the locations and diameter range of ultrasonographically detectable ureteral stones in our pediatric patients whereas to report some practical points to ease the detection of ureteral stones with ultrasonography. Materials and methods Eighteen patients aged between 8 months and 15 years with sonograhically detectable ureteral stones were included. Abdominal ultrasonography was performed initially. The diagnosis of urolithiasis was confirmed by spontaneous discharge of stones, IVP, surgical procedures or clinical follow-up. A total of 12 males and 6 females with a mean age of 8.7 years underwent abdominal sonography examination with 3-3.5 MHz convex and 7.5-8 MHz lineer probes. Detection of hyperechogenic structure with little or prominent posterior acustic shadowing in a dilated ureter lumen was accepted as diagnostic criteria for ureteral stone. Results In 14 patients (78%), stones were located in distal ureter lumen, whereas in 4 patients (22%) they were located in proximal ureter lumen. In 9 cases (50%) ureteral stones were on the right side and in 9 cases (50%)were on the left. The diameter of the smallest ureteral stone was measures as 2.4 mm and of the largest one was measured as 8.3 mm (mean diameter of ureteral stones was 5 mm).

During the ultrasonographic examination, the best results were obtained when the patients were in supine position elevating their examined side from the bed between 30 and 90°. Distal ureteral stones were best examined with mild to moderate bladder filling. Overfilling of urinary bladder was a limitating factor for probe maneuvers to detect stones. Conclusion Ultrasonography is a rapid, efficient and safe method to diagnose proximal and distal ureteral stones.
