CT image guided percutaneous core needle biopsy of bone lessions in children Evanthia Botsa 1 , Ioannis Koutsogiannis 2 , Evaggelia Sotiropoulou 3 , Paraskevi Tsagouli 3 , Odysseas Konstantinopoulos 3 , Loukas Thanos 3 1. Agıa Sofia Children's Hospital Athens 2. Bioiatriki Medical Center, Athens 3. Sotiria General Hospital, Athens 4. Tzaneio General Hospital, Athens

Objective Accurate diagnosis of bone lesions is important for its successful management. Ct image guided CNB is an acute and safe diagnostic procedure in evaluating bone lesions in children, especially those in areas of diagnostic difficulty. Materials and methods The total number of patients included in this retrospective study was 42. The mean age was 8 years, with a range of 2-14 years. For the whole series there were patients with lesions of the shoulder, pelvis, iliac, cervical spine, lumbar spine, thoracic spine and femoral bone. All biopsies were performed under sedation. The bone tissue was obtained using cutting trocar system 14G with a needle of 18G. Results Adequate diagnostic histological material was obtained in 38 out of 42 patients of our cases (90.4%). Four of our patients underwent the procedure for a second time in order to get adequate material for the diagnosis. The histological findings were in 6 patients osteosarcoma, 4 chondrosarcoma, 4 chondroblastoma, 5 lymphoma, 6 istiocytossis, 5 tuberculosis spondilitis, 8 staphylococcal spondilitis. One patient had a small osteoid osteoma of the cotyle, in this case we managed not only to take a tissue sample but to remove the whole nidus. None of our patients had any major complications. Conclusion CT image guided percutaneous CNB of bone lesions is a diagnostically helpful, effective, secure, minimally invasive procedure that can be performed in children. The benefit is more obvious when the lesion is deep seated in the pelvis or spine or very closely related to the neurovascular structure.

Primary fluoroscopic gastrojejunostomy placement in infants with mutliple comorbidities Meguru Watanabe, Horacio Padua, Ahmad Alomari, Gulraiz Chaudry Children's Hospital Boston, USA Background Primary fluoroscopic gastrojejunostomy (GJ) tube placement offers a minimally invasive method of jejunal feeding in children of all ages. Objective We present a review of GJ placement in children less than 12 months old, in whom severe comorbidities precluded a surgical or endoscopic procedure. We review the technique and evaluate the efficacy of the procedure and associated complications. Materials and methods The medical records and imaging were reviewed in all infants who had a primary radiologic GJ tube placement in a 2 year period. The underlying condition and indication for placement was noted. The technique and the catheter used was also documented. Finally, immediate and long-term outcomes were assessed, including major and minor complications. Results There were 14 infants (6 m, 8 f). The mean age was 4.1 m and the mean weight was 4.2 kg. The primary diagnosis was prematurity with feeding difficulties in 4, complex cardiac disease in 4, neurodevelopmental disorder in 2, respiratory compromise in 2 and GI disorder in 2. The indication was reflux/aspiration in all and poor feeding in 6. A 8.5 F Cook or 10 F Carey-Alzate catheter was used. Mean follow-up period was 16.8 months. One patient died from the underlying cause unrelated to the procedure. The other 13 patients (93%) had a functioning GJ tube at the end of the follow up periods. These 13 patients gained weight along the normal growth curve. There were no major or intra-procedural complications. Minor complications included a leak around the tube in 3 patients (21%), skin erythema in 3 (21%), displacement of the catheter (43%) in 6 and granulation at the skin insertion site in 2 (14%). Conclusion Primary fluoroscopic gastrojejunostomy tube insertion in infants is effective and safe, even in the presence of significant comorbidities.

Symptomatic hepatic cyst in a child: treatment with single-shot injection of tetracycline hydrochloride G Fabrizzi, C Lanza, G Pieroni, V Bolli, V Galeazzi, B Fabrizzi, A Martino Azienda Ospedaliero-Universitaria Ospedali Riuniti, Italy

Background Treatment of symptomatic hepatic cysts is problematic and controversial. Surgery has been the traditional therapy, but it carries a high morbidity rate. Percutaneous aspiration alone is only transiently effective. The combination of aspiration and sclerotherapy has provided good results. Objective We review the treatment of symptomatic solitary hepatic cysts in childhood and described a pediatric case of benign hepatic cyst successfully treated by the instillation of tetracycline hydrochloride (HCL). Materials and methods A 11 years old boy was admitted to our pediatric hospital for abdominal pain. Ultrasound and MRI scans showed a large solitary hepatic cyst of 5.2×6.2×9.4 cm (volume 160 cc) in the posterior liver segment. The cyst was punctured with a 21-gauge Chiba needle under at real-time US imaging. After aspiration of 10 cc of the cyst content, the cyst was opacified by injecting the same volume of iomeprol, a non ionic contrast agent, under fluoroscopic guide to check for the absence of communication between the cyst and the biliary tree and to test for the absence of leak into the peritoneal cavity. After that 200 mg of tetracycline HCL solution (5%) was injected into the cystic cavity and wasn't aspirated before needle removal. This injection was performed only once. Results Complete regression was found at 3 months US and MR examination with total collapse of the cyst. No immediate or late complications occurred and the patient have remained symptom free. Conclusion To our knowledge, this is the first pediatric case reported in literature where a solitary liver cyst was treated with sclerotherapy using tetracycline HCL. We propose that injection of tetracycline HCL is in pediatric patients an efficient and safe treatment with short hospitalization.

Complications of image-guided gastrostomies and gastrojejunostomies in children and their management Francoise Rypens, Josée Dubois, Laurent Garel, Valérie Marchand, Dickens Saint-Vil, Louise Lalande Department of Imaging, Hospital Ste-Justine, Canada

Background Gatrostomies and gastrojejunostomies are two well established methods of providing long-term enteral nutrition in children where oral intake is not sufficient to maintain adequate caloric and nutritional support. Surgery, endoscopy, and interventional radiology can all provide the percutaneous access. Eventhough the radiologic guided procedure is the least invasive of the three methods, complications related to the procedure do occur, some of them potentially lethal, and tube maintenance issues (TMIs) are frequent. Objective -To present and demonstrate major and minor complications, and TMIs observed after image-guided procedures, and to discuss circumstances of occurrence, and management procedures.

-To illustrate the complementary role of interventional radiology after endoscopic or surgical procedures. Materials and methods Retrospective analysis of the radiological and clinical data of all children who underwent image-guided gastrostomies and gastrojejunostomies in the department of medical imaging of our institution. Review of the literature. Results Events occurring during the procedure include: access failure, access loss, difficulty in obtaining access, retention suture loss, pneumoperitoneum, hemorrhage, misplacement, bowel transfixion, and hepatic or splenic injuries.Postprocedural complications include: peritonitis, sepsis, ileus, accidental dislodgment, bowel obstruction due to intussusception or retained fragment, tube migration, site infections, site discomfort), and TMIs (granulomas, tube breaks, obstructions, leakage, migration, dislodgment and displacements) are described and discussed. TMIs include granulomas, and tube breaks, obstructions, leakages, migrations, dislodgments and displacements. Conclusion Percutaneous placement of gastrostomies and gastrojejunostomies is a team work. In our experience, the most serious complications occured in immunocompromised patients. Small babies were more prone to tube displacement and bowel obstruction than older patients. Specifically designed material is still lacking for small children. TMIs usually require to change the tube.

Symptomatic parapelvic renal cyst: Treatment of single-session percutaneous drainage and ethanol sclerotherapy Medine Boge, Turkmen Ciftci, Devrim Akinci, Okan Akhan Faculty of Medicine, Hacettepe University, Ankara, Turkey

Background A 12 year-old girl with symptomatic parapelvic renal cyst was treated by percutaneous drainage and ethanol sclerotherapy which is widely used as an effective and non-invasive treatment method in symptomatic simple renal cysts. Material and methods Procedure was performed under local anesthesia and intravenous sedation in prone position . After the puncture of the 3 cm parapelvic cyst with 20 G Chiba needle under ultrasonographic guidance; cystogram was obtained to evaluate the communication with the pelvicalyceal system and retroperitoneal extravasation. Then 95% ethanol of 30-40% of the initial cyst volume, as the sclerosing agent, was injected into the cystic cavity. The ethanol was left into the cavity for 10 min to destroy cyst epithelium. At the end of the procedure ethanol was reaspirated and the needle was withdrawn. Results After the sclerotheraphy the cyst was followed by sonography 1, 3, 6 and 12 months after the procedure and yearly afterwards. For a period of 3 years and six months follow-up, the patient was completely symptom-free (pain and upper pole hydonephrosis) and the cyst showed complete resolution. Discussion The parapelvic renal cysts are originated from renal parenchyma and lying down to the renal hilus. Most are asymptomatic but if a parapelvic cyst becomes symptomatic, the treatment is necessary. Percutaneous drainage and ethanol sclerotherahy is performed mainly in cortical cysts. However, it is less commonly experienced in parapelvic cysts due to needle course through the renal parenchyma and proximity of the cyst to the renal hilus.
In our case total resolution of the cyst and symptoms could be achieved with single session sclerotherapy.

Odontogenic cysts, tumors and fibro-osseous lesions in children: A radiological pictorial case report Azian Abd Aziz 1 , Vincent C Jesu 2 , S Yogeswari 2 1. International Islamic University Malaysia 2. Hospital Tengku Ampuan Afzan, Kuantan, Pahang, Malaysia

These include dentigerous cyst, odontogenic keratocysts, calcifying odontogenic cyst, ameloblastoma, adenomatoid odontogenenic tumor and ossifying fibroma. All the cases were confirmed on histology. Background There are about 300 lymph nodes in the neck. All of them can be easily examined with ultrasonography (US). Similar to the other ones, neck lymph nodes also can enlarge abnormally due to different causes (enfectious, inflamatory or neoplastic). Sometimes reactivated neck lymph nodes in the pediatric population may loose their normal central fatty echogenity. In this instance, size can be the most important parameter to establish the abnormal node(s). Regretfully saying, we couldn't found any other study in the literature that has mentioned the normal sizes of the neck lymph nodes in normal pediatric population. Objective The purpose of this prospective study was to measure the cervical lymph node sizes in normal pediatric cases and to present a scale for guiding sonographist. Materials and methods A total 104 patients were included (mean age 9.4 years, m:63, F:41) in study. Complete blood count and routine biochemistry of the patients were also done. The imaging characteristics of lymphangiomas: Pictorial essay Harvey EL Teo KK Women's and Children's Hospital Background Lymphangiomas or cystic hygromas are congenital malformations of the lymphatic system. It is important to accurately diagnose these lesions to ensure appropriate management and therapy. Whilst these lesions are benign, they can be extensively infiltrative causing local symptoms requiring therapy. Occasionally, aggressive mixed lyphangiomatous and vascular tumours of the soft tissues may occur. Objective This pictorial essay will demonstrate the imaging characteristics of lymphangiomas in paediatric patients on ultrasound, CT and MRI. Familiarity with the imaging features will enable the radiologist to accurately assess, diagnose and stage these lesions. Results Lymphangiomas appear as transcompartmental multiloculated cystic lesions. The cystic areas are circumscribed and discrete. Marginal enhancement on cross-sectional imaging is usually present. Ultrasound is useful in the evaluation of small superficial lesions but is limited in determining the extent of spread in larger and deeper lesions. CT is useful in diagnosing and staging these lesions but results in exposure to ionizing radiation. The contrast resolution of CT is also inferior to MRI which is the modality of choice. The superior contrast resolution on MRI makes it the most sensitive modality for diagnosing and determining the extent of spread of these lesions. MRI can also diagnose mixed lesions by demonstrating flow signal changes and tubular, enhancing vascular channels within these lesions. Conclusion The ability of the different imaging modalities to appropriately diagnose and stage lymphangiomas in children is important and will be demonstrated in this pictorial essay. Background Congenital anomalies of the aortic arch and its branches are commonly encountered in radiological practice. A right-sided aortic arch (RAA) with an aberrant left subclavian artery (ALSA) is a rare anomaly that occurs in 0.05% of the population. Duplicated vertebral artery anomaly is very rare either depicted incidentally in autopsy series, or angiographic studies including noninvazive MR and CT angiographic studies which have been increasingly utilized in daily practice.

Objective To present MDCT angiographic findings of an unusual case of duplicated left vertebral artery associated with right-sided aortic arch and aberrant left subclavian artery. Materials and methods The barium swallow of a 7-year-old boy revealed a posterior impression to esophagus on the lateral view suggesting vascular ring. MDCT angiography was performed subsequently to provide the definitive diagnosis by using a 16-slice MDCT scanner. 3D volume-rendered and maximum-intensity-projection images were obtained from the axial images. Results MDCT angiography identified RAA with ALSA arise from a diverticulum of Kommerell located posterior to the esophagus. No airway compression was identified. Both vessels coursed straight up and united at C6 vertebral level to continue as the LVA and entered the foramen transversarium at the same level. The right vertebral artey was normal originating from the right subclavian artery. Conclusion During the long life span of the children, vascular anomalies may become important in the planning of interventional and surgical procedures. Radiologists should be familiar with various types of vascular anomalies since wider application of MDCT angiography, with excellent 3D images, increased the incidence of these anomalies in daily practice. A pictorial ultrasonographic review of paediatric neck masses Caroline Corry, Kaseem Ajılogba Royal Hospital for Sick Children, Edinburgh, UK Background Neck masses are common findings in children. The knowledge of the neck spaces/compartments, defined by fascial planes, and their contents provides an approach to differential diagnosis. Intracranial haemorrhage in childhood haemophilia Kaseem Ajilogba 1 , Chris Barnes 2 , Michael Dithfield 2 1. Royal Hospital for Sick Children, Edinburgh 2. Royal Childrens' Hospital, Melbourne, Australia Background Haemophilia is an X-linked disorder due to a deficiency of factor VIII or IX characterised by joint and muscle haemorrhages and prolonged, potentially fatal haemorrhage after trauma or surgery. However, bleeding does occur at other sites such as intramuscular haematomas and the "closed-space" bleeding phenomenon. Intracranial haemorrhage, a "closed space" event, is a severe but uncommon complication of haemophilia. Objective The aim is to review the incidence of intracranial haemorrhage in children with haemophilia attending a tertiary paediatric centre. Materials and methods A retrospective review of patients identified by records maintained by the Henry Ekert Haemophilia Treatment Centre between January 1991 and December 2005 was done. The disease severity, general radiological investigations and specifically initial neuro-imaging were analysed and the incidence of intracranial haemorrhage matched with disease severity. Results 102 patients were identified (82 haemophilia A; 20 haemophilia B). Of these, 18 (18%), 19 (19%) and 65 (63%) had mild, moderate and severe disease respectively. Sixty-three (61.8%) patients (aged 3 months to 18.5 years, mean 8.4 years) required imaging, of which 7 (11.1%) had CT; 7 (11.1%) had ultrasonography and 49 (77.8%) had plain radiography. All in the CT group had examination of the head-5 (71%) were under 5 years of age and 2 (29%) under 7 years of age. Four (57%) had normal scans and 3 (43%) had nontraumatic intracranial haemorrhage; two of whom were under one year and the other, aged six. Two of those who had intracranial haemorrhage had moderate disease and the other, severe. Conclusion Intracranial haemorrhage is an uncommon but significant complication of childhood haemophilia that can be associated with significant morbidity and mortality. Education of patients, carers and medical professionals should also include advice on symptoms that must alert to possible intracranial haemorrhage.
Vascular anomalies made easy Philip John, Oscar Navarro, Joao Amaral and Dimitri Parra The Hospital for Sick Children, Toronto, Canada

Background Vascular anomalies in infants and children are clinically diverse and continue to pose clinical and radiological dilemmas. MR findings of Rosai Dorfman disease in two siblings with cervical masses that mimics lymphoma Sinan Akay, Veysel Akgun, Murat Kocaoglu, Cem Tayfun Gulhane Military Medical Faculty, Ankara, Turkey

Background Rosai-Dorfman disease (RDD), also known as sinus histiocytosis with massive lymphadenopathy, is a rare histiocytic proliferative disorder. Patients usually present with massive cervical lymphadenopathy but other nodal sites such as mediastinal or inguinal are also frequently involved. Objective To underline the importance of RDD in the differential diagnosis of the cervical lymphadenopathy in pediatric age group. Materials and methods 11 and 12 year-old two siblings with bilateral cervical lymphadenopathies admitted to our radiology department for Magnetic Resonance (MR) imaging for suspected lymphoma. Results In both patients, MR images demonstrated multiple massive lymphadenopathies in cervical regions mimicking lymphoma, one of the most common causes of malign lymphadenopathy in pediatric age group. No extranodal involvement was determined. In both cases, biopsies taken from cervical lymph nodes confirmed the diagnosis of RDD histopathologically. Conclusion Both of the cases showed that RDD must also be included in the list of differential diagnoses of diffuse and massive lymphadenopathy beside infectious/granulomatous conditions, lymphomatous and metastatic diseases.

Awolf in sheep's clothing-Serious pathology presenting as seemingly trivial lesions K Taylor-Robinson, C Farrell, S Harave, C Landes Alder Hey Children's NHS Foundation Trust, UK Background Urging readers to think outside the box we present a series of cases from a large children's hospital where the patient's first presentation was a seemingly classic example of fairly trivial pathology. On further investigation all of these patients were revealed to have serious, aggressive pathology including malignancy. Materials and methods Cases include an arm lesion which had the appearances of a simple haematoma which was later revealed to be a PNET metastasis and an inguinal hernia which was later shown to be a large intra-abdominal kaposiform haemangionendothelioma with life threatening consumptive coagulopathy. Conclusion In radiology as in all specialties doctors experience fatigue in frequently reporting trivial cases. We reflect upon the aspects of these cases that prompted further investigation. These cases highlight the need for vigilance in the assessment of common findings.

Background Several tumors or tumorlike lesions involve the orbital wall in children. They may arise directly from the orbital bones or secondarily involve the orbital wall via metastasis or via direct extension from other sites. They show a wide histological spectrum, from developmental anomalies to neoplastic and proliferative disorders, and cannot be differentiated through clinical findings. Imaging studies can play an important role in diagnosis and management of these lesions. Objective To present a pictorial review of clinical, imaging and pathologic features of orbital wall lesions in children.

The lesions that will be discussed include dermoid inclusion cyst, fibrous dysplasia, juvenile ossifying fibroma, Langerhans cell histiocytosis, granulocytic sarcoma, sinonasal mucocele, Ewing sarcoma/PNET, sinonasal lymphoma, sinonasal chondroma, plexiform neurofibroma, orbital bone metastases from neuroblastoma, and subperiosteal abscess. Results and conclusion Many lesions of the orbital wall in children such as dermoid inclusion cyst, fibrous dysplasia, sinonasal mucocele, plexiform neurofibroma, or subperiosteal abscess can be identified at imaging with their characteristic features. The others may show overlapping imaging findings. Nevertheless, a presumptive diagnosis may be suggested from imaging studies by understanding their clinical-radiologic-pathologic correlation. Materials and methods This is an iconographic selection from a retrospective review of radiology database from our institution for the last 8 years regarding Fluid Levels identified in various imaging studies including radiographs, US, CT as well as MRI.

Results Fluid levels are variable in nature: air/fluid versus fluid/fluid versus fluid/layering material levels. Multiple entities at different sites carry these signs such as cavities or infectious lesions or structures communicating with the airways seen of chest radiographs or CT. Air/ fluid levels are common in normal bowel but major ones represent intestinal obstruction. On CT of the peritoneal cavity they mean G I tract perforation or abscess collections. In the pelvic or cervical masses, fluid/fluid level heralds likely a hemorrhagic complication. Different ages of hemorrhage may be delineated with fluid levels on CT of a subdural hematoma. MRI brings more sensitivity to tissue contrast (different signal intensities of acute/chronic hemorrhage, slow flowing blood). Lipohemarthrosis level means communication between marrow space and joint space in skeletal trauma. Fluid/fluid levels, a non specific sign in musculoskeletal neoplasms, are encountered in aneurysmal bone cyst, synovial sarcoma, or bone cyst among others. Conclusion Fluid levels may be observed with all imaging modalities. Their clinical significance varies with the involved organ and the clinical settings.

Background Abnormalities of the vena cava system are usually asymptomatic, hemodynamically insignificant and discovered incidentally during CT scan. Recently-devised 3-dimensional (3D) diagnostic modalities such as magnetic resonance imaging and multi-slice computed tomography (MSCT) allow visualization of the great vessels from any angle of view and perspective. Among them, the MSCT examination provides highly contrasted 3D images of complicated congenital vascular anomalies. Objective The CT imaging appearances of the vena cava system anomalies are presented. In addition, the clinical relevance of the variations is discussed. Materials and methods We reviewed records of 4 children hemodynamically asymptomatic (mean age 4 years) that underwent MSCT for surgical abdominal planning. Results CT scans showed 2 duplications of the IVC and 2 persistent left superior vena cava (PLSVC) In double IVC the left IVC end at the confluence with the left renal vein which crosses anterior to the aorta in the normal fashion to join a normal prerenal IVC. Patients with bilateral superior vena cava (SVC) had a normal rightSVC and a PLSVC. Conclusion Vascular structures are usually readily identified on MSCT scans of the abdomen and pelvis obtained with intravenously administered contrast material. The MSCT is a promising tool for the precise diagnosis and planning of surgical operation. Awareness of these anomalies is necessary to avoid diagnostic pitfalls.

MRI appearances of sensorineural hearing loss in paediatric patients C Farrell, K Taylor-Robinson, S Harave, M Tawil Alder Hey Hospital, UK Abstract MRI Appearances of Sensorineural Hearing Loss (SNHL) in paediatric patients Background Sensorineural deafness is the paediatric population can be either congenital or acquired. Traditionally plain film and CT have been used to image patients with SNHL but the superior soft tissue detail provided by MRI has resulted in its becoming the investigation of choice. MRI allows visualisation of the cochlear nerve which is crucial to the planning of cochlear nerve implants, detail which is not seen on CT. This technique also avoids the use of ionising radiation.

Objective We present a pictorial review of some of the common and more unusual MRI findings in SNHL as seen in a tertiary referral paediatric hospital. These include examples of cochlear nerve absence and hypolasia, vestibular aqueduct dilatation and semicircular canal abnormalities. Less frequently seen intracranial causes are also discussed. Conclusion Interpretation of MRI of the inner ear is an important skill for any paediatric radiologist. We aim to provide an accessible pictorial review of MRI inner ear findings.
Traumatic abdominal wall herniation Ferda Bacaksizlar Sari, F Demir Apaydin, Meltem Nass Duce, Engin Kara Department of Radiology, Faculty of Medicine, Mersin University, Mersin, Turkey

Background Traumatic abdominal wall herniation is a rare condition, which occurs secondary to blunt abdominal trauma. When intraabdominal pressure increases suddenly or splitting forces are applied to the abdominal wall, traumatic abdominal wall herniation takes place from anatomic weak areas. The diagnosis is often done by means of physical examination, which however can be difficult because of the abdominal wall tenderness, or by abdominal computed tomography (CT). Objective Our aim is to present a case of traumatic abdominal wall herniation and to discuss the relevant literature. Materials and methods A 21-months-old boy, who was overrun by a tractor, was admitted to our hospital. On admission, he had diffuse abdominal tenderness. He was conscious. Physical examination revealed a tender bulging mass and ecchymosis on the left upper quadrant of the abdomen. We examined the patient by chest x-ray, plain abdominal film and abdominopelvic CT exam which was performed by a 64-slice multidetector CT. Results His chest X-ray and abdominal plain film were normal. On the CT of the abdomen and pelvis, an abdominal wall herniation on the left upper quadrant was demonstrated and the small bowel loops were shown to be located subcutaneously in the anterior thoracic wall. The patient was operated and the defect was repaired. Conclusion Traumatic abdominal wall herniations are rare in pediatric population. In children with diffuse abdominal tenderness following a blunt abdominal trauma, the possibility of such a diagnosis should be remembered even if the chest x-rays or the abdominal plain films are normal. In such cases, CT can be considered as a useful diagnostic tool. Background Computerized tomography (CT) is used widely as first screening method for blunt abdominal trauma (BAT). The risk related to radiation is increased especially in children under that issue. The knowledge of usefulness of ultrasound (US) in management of patients with BAT will decrease unnecessary CT examination. Objective To assess the importance of the US finding of free intraperitoneal fluid without solid organ injury after BAT in children.

The clinical and imaging data of 130 children admitted to emergency department between July 2007 and December 2008 with BAT were reviewed retrospectively. All children had an abdominal US as the primary screening method. Patients without solid-organ injury and with free intraperitoneal fluid at US examination were included. Intraperitoneal fluid was localized. US results were compared with findings of CT, diagnostic peritoneal lavage, laparotomy and clinical course. Results US examination revealed free fluid and/or solid-organ injury in 8 and only free intraperitoneal fluid in 14 patients. Two (14%) out of 14 patients had intrabdominal organ injury (one solid-organ injury, the other one intestinal injury required an operation). Among the 108 patients with negative finding at US, only one had solid-organ injury (false negative). Intraperitoneal fluid was located in pelvis in eight patients with two of them had pelvic wall injury. Fluid was involved the pelvis and abdomen in six patients: two had intrabdominal injury; one was surgical. All but one were followed up at emergency unit or hospitalized without need of any surgery and discharged. Conclusion US is an effective screening method in hemodynamically stable patients with BAT. Because the risk of serious intraabdominal injury is low in patients with only free fluid in pelvis detected by US, it seems sufficient to follow up clinically of these patients. The presence of free fluid beside pelvis in any location needs additional imaging methods. Objective The aim of this study is to investigate the spectrum and prevalence of ultrasonographic findings of the spleen in these patients.

The study included 72 patients with sicklecell disease, 15 homozygous for sickle-cell anemia (S/S) and 57 with sickle β thalassemia (Th/S). The patients' age ranged from 1 to 40 years, with 40 males and 32 females. At the time of ultrasonographic examination 32 patients had already undergone splenectomy (4/15 with S/S and 28/57 with Th/S). Results Splenomegaly was present in 26 patients (24 with Th/S and 2 with S/S) with detectable infarcts in 11/26 patients. Mild, moderate and marked splenomegaly shared equal percentages (33%) among patients with Th/S and splenomegaly. Marked splenomegaly was present in two patients with S/S. A small sized, calcified spleen was visualized in 4 patients with S/S. Splenic nodules were revealed in two patients with S/S. They were homogeneous and isoechoic or slightly hyperechoic to the splenic parenchyma. MR imaging in these patients confirmed the presence of these nodules, hyperintense in T1 and T2 weighted images. Conclusion Ultrasound imaging has an undisputable value in detecting complications of sickle-cell syndromes. One should be aware of findings' variations so as to avoid further unnecessary examinations. In S/S patients, splenic nodules may be revealed, and their benign nature can be confirmed by MR.

Evaluation of venous anomalies in klipppel-trenaunay syndrome with direct CT venography evaluation of venous anomalies in Klipppel-Trenaunay syndrome Ertugrul Mavili, Yigit Akcali, Halil Donmez, Ali Yikilmaz, Selim Dogan, Mehmet Ozturk Medical Faculty, Erciyes University, Kayseri, Turkey

Background Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome is a rare combination of complex vascular malformations. There are different noninvasive and invasive techniques to assess KTS. CT venography (MDCTV) is a new modality that may be used for complete assessment of vascular abnormalities in KTS. Objective To evaluate the effectiveness of multidetector CT venography for the evaluation of lower extremity anomalies in Klipppel-Trenaunay Syndrome (KTS). Materials and methods Eight pediatric patients with KTS were included in the study. The clinical findings were recorded and a CT venogram was obtained by using a 16-slice multidetector CT scanner after administration of contrast material via superficial veins of the dorsal feet. CT images were evaluated for soft tissue thickening, bone hypertrophy, and for the abnormalities of superficial and deep veins by using axial, MPR, MIP and volume-rendered images. Results Six patients were KTS type 1 and 2 patients were KTS type 2. In 6 patients blotchy stains were seen while the other 2 patients did not have stains. All patients had soft tissue thickening and three patients had hypertrophy of the affected limb. Venous abnormalities were present in all the patients. Varicose veins were the most encountered abnormality. Femoral vein and popliteal vein were the most common involved veins in 7 and 6 patients; respectively. Vena cava inferior was affected in 2 patients. Volume rendered and MIP images were effective for demonstrating the whole venous system in its full length; however, in one patients the femoral veins were not seen on MIP and volume-rendered images and sectional images were able to demonstrate these hypoplastic femoral veins. Conclusion Multidetector CT venography provides the opportunity of evaluating the whole venous system together with bone and soft tissue abnormalities in only one examination. The axial, MPR, MIP and volume-rendered images should be evaluated together in order to avoid misinterpretations.

Hydatid disease (HD): What about unusual locations in pediatric population? S Deftereos, A Oikonomou, P Mintzopoulou, A Spanoudaki, E Vranou, P Prassopoulos University General Hospital of Alexandroupolis, Greece Background HD is a worldwide parasitic disease produced by the larval stage of Echinococcus, endemic in central and northern Europe, the Mediterranean, northern Asia, China, Japan, Turkey and parts of North America. Liver and lungs, in children, are the organs most frequently affected with typical and well known imaging findings. On the other hand, unusual anatomic locations, the related imaging findings and rare manifestations of HD are less frequently described. Objective To discuss the prevalence and imaging findings of unusual anatomic locations of HD in pediatric population. Materials and methods Radiological findings range from purely cystic to completely solid lesions that can be solitary or multiple. They can become quite large, especially the pulmonary lesions and in some atypical cases growth rate may overcome duplication annually. Calcification is rarely seen in pulmonary locations but is often in liver, spleen and kidney. Gallbladder, biliary, adrenal, peritoneal and brain locations are rare and may exhibit findings not similar to liver HD. Exophytic growth and transdiaphragmatic migration of liver HD is a rare manifestation. The diagnostic tool indicated depends on the organ involved and the evolution stage of the disease. US is the method of choice in purely cystic lesions, with floating membranes and daughter cysts. CT is preferred for chest diagnosis and is best for demonstrating calcifications and complications. MR imaging is especially helpful in detecting HCs of the central nervous system. Conclusion Familiarity with unusual locations of HD and atypical radiological manifestations enables usage of best diagnostic tools and accurate diagnosis of the disease. Background The major morbidity and cause of death during extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) are related to neurological complications. Early diagnosis is important to guide further treatment. However, diagnostic methods available during ECMO are limited, especially in older children. MRI is a sensitive and reliable method for assessment of brain parenchymal changes. We have previously reported an animal experiment with MRI during ECMO. However, the use of MRI in patients during ECMO has to our knowledge never been reported. Objective We report the first successful MRI examination of a patient during ECMO treatment. Materials and methods An eight-year-old boy with proven haemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) was admitted to the paediatric intensive care with sepsis and ARDS after operation of an intussusception and bowel necrosis. Progressive cardiopulmonary insufficiency necessi-tated ECMO-treatment. During the treatment seizures and intermittent hypertension with dilated pupils were noted. Cranial CT showed bilateral hypodense regions in the basal ganglia and thalami but could not differentiate toxic oedema from infarction/necrosis. Therefore the patient was prepared for MRI using non-wired cannulas, 2 m extra tubing and a mobile ECMO-system that we had previously tested for MRI. The brain was examined with conventional imaging including diffusion weighted imaging and proton spectroscopy. Results High quality images of the brain were obtained without disturbing the function of the ECMO system. Spectroscopy was successfully conducted with clear visualization of pathological metabolites. As expected MRI provided critical information for the lesions characterization and extension. Widespread infarction/necrosis with hemorrhagic components were diagnosed in the basal ganglia, thalami, brainstem and corticospinal tracts. Conclusion MRI can safely be performed and provide important information in patients with neurological complications during ECMO treatment.

Congenital infiltrating lipoma of foot, trunk and face: Report of three cases Sureyya B Gorkem 1 , Mustafa Ozturk 1 , Ali Yikilmaz 1 , Atilla Coruh 2 1. Department of Radiology, Medical School, Erciyes University 2. Department of Plastic Surgery, Medical School, Erciyes University Abstract Infiltrating lipomas are seen more frequently after 30-40 years of age. They are uncommon in children. Only few pediatric cases have been described in the literature. Infiltrating lipomas have congenital and acquired forms. The congenital form is typically seen before 2 years of age. In this paper we describe three pediatric congenital infiltrating lipomas with localization of face, trunk and foot. Report We report a 6 month-old girl with a soft mobile mass on her cheek causing facial asymmetry and ptotic lip, a 1 year old boy with a soft mass on his left foot which had been growing since his birth and a 1 year old boy with a soft mass on his left paravertebral space. The masses were mobile and ill-defined. For each cases MRI were carried out. MRI showed that the lesions had lipom-like signal intensity and were infiltrating the adjacent structures. Surgical decompression were performed. Histopathologic examinations revealed mature adipose tissue without any nuclear atypia. On the routine controls the rest of lipomas were observed without any change in size. Discussion MRI is the best imaging technique to diagnose soft tissue tumors. We can easily observe the homogenous fatty tissue invading the adjacent structures as a common feature of the infiltrating lipomas in our cases. But only clinical examination or MRI can not be reliably to differentiate lipoma, liposarcoma and lipoblastoma. To diagnose the lipoma histolopathological examination is usually required.

Finally infiltrating lipomas should be included in the differential diagnosis of soft fatty tissue tumors in childhood although they were common in adults. We also found out that MRI was the best imaging modality to establish the infiltrating pattern of the tumors and to insure satisfactory outcome on the follow-up in our cases.

The imaging features of fibrous dysplasia of the head and neck in children: A pictorial essay Harvey EL Teo, Wilfred CG Peh, Kok Chye Tan KK Women's and Children's Hospital, Alexandra Hospital, National University Hospital Fibrous dysplasia is a benign localized bone disorder of unknown aetiology which may affect one or more bones. Endocrinopathies, abnormal pigmentation of the skin and mucous membranes are often associated with the disease. Fibrous dysplasia involving the head and neck often produces marked cosmetic and functional complications due to cranial nerve compression. This pictorial essay will illustrate the wide range of various presentations and radiological appearances of this entity as seen on different imaging modalities such as plain radiographs, computerized tomography and magnetic resonance imaging.

body_text.text: Evaluation of workflow in a pediatric radiology department using ultra low dose digital imaging system M Alison, R Azoulay, B Tilea, S Grandjean, T Lefevre, I Achour, G Sebag Hôpital Robert Debré, AP-HP, Paris VII University Background A new Ultra Low Dose digital imaging system (EOS, biospace med, Paris) allows simultaneous AP and LAT direct acquisition of whole or partial body images, of a patient in an upright or seated position, favorable for musculoskeletal examinations. The dose is 5 to 10 times lower than currently used systems.

Objective The aim of this study was to evaluate the workflow of this Ultra Low Dose digital imaging system in a pediatric radiology department. Materials and methods 100 patients with a mean age of 13.3 years (SD=3.5 years, range 4-19 years) undertook an EOS examination. Acquisitions were performed by one technician only. The study included full body, full spine, lower limb, chest, pelvis, knee, shoulder and extremity acquisitions. Examination time was recorded and compared to the existing literature. Examination Time was recorded from the arrival of the child and ended when images were sent to PACS. Results Mean examination time was 3 min and 40 s for full body, full spine and lower limb, and 2 min and 30 s for the other investigated areas. Comparison with available literature showed that EOS provides better workflow than CR and equivalent or better than DR. Time gain is particularly high for long length examinations since the image is acquired in one single scan. Conclusion Ultra Low Dose Radiology improved the workflow in a paediatric radiology department. Spine and lower limb examinations could be performed in less than 4 minutes.

A pictorial review of the radiology and differential diagnosis of metaphyseal. Abnormalities in children S Harave, K Taylor-Robinson, C Farrell, C Landes Alder Hey Children's Hospital, UK Background The metaphyses are the most vascular and active part of the growing long bone and as such they are affected by various systemic and local diseases. There are a variety of manifestations of these diseases and some appearances are pathognomonic while others have a wider differential diagnosis. Common conditions such as Rickets and trauma will be included whilst other rarer pathologies such as congenital Rubella and metaphyseal dysplasias will also be discussed. Objective We aim to present a pictorial review of the varied appearances of the metaphyses in children seen at a tertiary children's hospital.

> A brief description of the pathologic process responsible for these > appearances will be included Conclusion Knowledge of the radiological appearances of metaphyses is invaluable in assessing radiographs of long bones and skeletal surveys in children and can be diagnostic. Awareness of the background pathologic process responsible for these appearances will aid in the differential diagnosis.
A case with proximal femoral focal deficiency and fibular agenesis Gulten Coskun, Melda Apaydin, Aysegul Sarsilmaz, Makbule Varer, Engin Uluc Izmir Ataturk Egitim ve Arastirma Hastanesi, Turkey

Objective We report a case of bilateral proximal femoral focal deficiency (PFFD) together with fibular aplasia associated with unilateral undescended testis and bilateral inguinal herni. Some congenital anomalies involving face, gastrointestinal, skeletal and urogenital system, heart, lung and diaphragma associated with lower limb malformations have been described in the literature.

The male infant is the first child of healthy nonconsanguineous parents. Family history and pregnancy were unremarkable. There was no history of maternal diabetes or exposure to any teratogenic agent during the pregnancy. Physical examination revealed a shorter right lower limb compared to the left. Bilateral upper extremity and face were normal.

Radiographic examinations showed marked hypoplasia of the proximal 3/4 portion of the right femur and no absent acetabuler component. There were bilateral fibular, patellar agenesis and rotastion anomalies. The foot radiographs revealed tarsal agenesis, two metatarsal bones and phalanges, four metatarsal bones and phalanges on the left. There was no pathology on chest roentgenograms.

The application of open reduction and relaxastion operation for with PFFD of the right hip in four month man is described. When he was five rotation osteotomy for left foot wrist and walking ortesis for right lower extremity were applied. He started walking at the age of 5. Proximal femoral focal deficiency is a rare malformation of the lower limbs that involves the femur and acetabulum in varying degrees. Its etiology is multi-factorial, comprising cellular malnutrition, drug ingestion, vascular abnormality, and intra-uterine arterial compression. PFFD can be unilateral or bilateral and is associated with musculoskeletal defects distal to the femur such as fibula hemimelia and clubfoot. Urogenital anomalies that can be associated with PFFD are described as hypospadias, cryptorchidism, small penis, vaginal septum, double uterus, vesico-ureteric reflux, ectopic ureteric orifices, and pelvi-ureteric obstruction.
MR imaging findings of a hibernoma of the wrist: A case report Ayca Akgoz, Murat Canyigit, Ali Koksal, Okan Akhan Bayindir Hospitals, Ankara, Turkey

Background A 14-year-old girl with a history of painless subcutaneous mass in her left wrist for one month. Objective To present magnetic resonance imaging findings of hibernoma with a very unusual location.

Materials and methods Left wrist magnetic resonance imaging was performed with a 1.5T GE Signa EXCITE scanner using knee coil. Following sequences were acquired; coronal T1W,fat-saturated T2W, gradient-echo, transverse T1W, fat-saturated T2W, sagittal fatsaturated PDW, coronal 3D Fiesta, transverse fat-saturated T1W and coronal fat-saturated 3D T1W and following contrast administration transverse fat-saturated T1W and coronal fat-saturated 3D T1W. Results Physical examination revealed an immobile, painless leftsided wrist mass without any neurologic symptoms. Laboratory tests are within normal range. MR imaging depicted a lobulated, welldemarcated left-sided wrist mass located on the volar ulnar side, with a size of 25×12×23 mm, demonstrating intermediate signal intensity on T1W images and high signal intensity on T2W fat-saturated images and showing intense enhancement on postcontrast images. The mass was excised completely and the histopathologic examination showed that it was a hibernoma. Conclusion Hibernoma is a a rare benign tumor of brown fat origin. Hibernomas seem to form in the areas with remaining brown fat, such as the scapular region, neck, axilla, chest wall, mediastinum, perirenal areas, thigh, buttock, popliteal fossa, scalp, breast, periureteric region, and scrotum. The presented case showed that hibernoma should be considered in the differential diagnosis of benign tumors which are clinically slow-growing, painless and subcutaneously located.
Imaging approach to soft tissue lumps in pediatric patients MG Papadaki, H Moschouris, E Bouma, C Hadjigeorgi, D Matsaidonis Department of Radiology, "Tzanion" Hospital of Piraeus, Greece

Background Soft tissue lumps is a common indication for US in children. Normal structures are usually easily depicted but when a mass is present, its US characteristics may contribute significantly to the correct diagnosis. MRI should be performed when diagnosis is obscure.

Objective The aim of this study is to present normal anatomical structures and variants that can mimick soft tissue masses in children, to highlight the role of ultrasonography (US) as the first imaging modality in the evaluation of soft tissue tumors and to emphasize the importance of MRI in doubtful cases. Materials and methods In most cases US can confirm confidently the presence of a mass. It can distinguish between cystic and solid lesions, depict the tumor echo-structure and inform about its relationship with surrounding tissues. Pattern of vascularity adds valuable information. MRI is performed in doubtful cases, when extent of the lesion is difficult to define or malignancy is suspected. Results US usually proves sufficient for the diagnosis of bifid ribs, asymmetric costal cartilages and subcutaneous fat in children as well as for the diagnosis of common benign masses (cellulitis, lipoma, abcess, haematoma, fibromatosis coli, Baker's cyst, ganglia). Infantile haemangioma, venous haemangioma, A-V malformation and lymphangioma present with specific US features. MRI is used to define the extent of the lesion or where a soft tissue sarcoma is suspected. Conclusion US is the initial imaging method of choice for the evaluation of soft tissue lumps in children. It can often provide a specific diagnosis, especially in benign conditions. MRI adds informations in selected cases.

body_text.text: Osteopenia of prematurity: Pathophysiology and radiological features K Taylor-Robinson, S Harave, C Landes Alder Hey CHildren's NHS Foundation Trust, UK Background Osteopenia of prematurity is an important condition with a high prevalence in babies of low birth weight becoming more frequent with increasing prematurity. The condition is also termed metabolic bone disease of prematurity and includes the more specific condition of neonatal rickets. Presenting 6-12 weeks after birth there may be fractures, radiological signs of osteopenia or rickets, and abnormal bone biochemistry.

The etiology of osteopenia of prematurity is complex and multifactorial. Risk factors include: gestation less than 28 weeks; birth weight less than 1,500 g; prolongued TPN >4 weeks; exposure to steroids or diuretics; and periods of immobilisation. Objective We present an educational exhibit on Osteopenia of Prematurity highlighting the contributing pathophysiology and radiological findings. Materials and methods We reviewed the radiology of at risk patients, with 2 or more risk factors, that were in patients in a large specialist neonatal unit for a 12 month period from June 2007 to June 2008.
We present our findings, including the number and type of fractures, and use examples to demonstrate the features of osteopenia of prematurity.

The presentation of osteopenia of prematurity can coincide with discharge from the neonatal unit and as such the presence of multiple fractures can raise concerns regarding non-accidental injury, a known risk following premature birth. We highlight the differences in the typical findings whilst acknowledging that neither diagnosis can be made on radiological features alone. Conclusion Familiarity with the risk factors and presentation of osteopenia of prematurity is essential for those radiologists who report neonatal radiographs. This exhibit gives a rapid overview, arming the paediatric radiologist with the key information to make their assessment. Background CRMO is a rare inflammatory bone disease of unknown aetiology occurring mainly in children and adolescents. It may be difficult to distinguish CRMO from other bone diseases such as bacterial osteomyelitis or primary bone tumours. Diagnosis of CRMO is often delayed. Objective To review typical and atypical imaging patterns in order to prevent misdiagnosis and therefore, to avoid unnecessary invasive procedures or prolonged antibiotic therapy. Materials and methods We retrospectively reviewed clinical and imaging (X rays, CT, scintigraphy and MRI) findings of 21 children with CRMO. Diagnosis was based on the following criteria: (1) age under 18 years, (2) two different sites (at least) of bone involvement or one site associated to a fluctuating course with at least 2 recurrent episodes of pain and (3) surgical biopsy to exclude infectious and tumoral processes. Results The sex ratio was 2/1 (14 girls and 7 boys) and the age range 3-18 years. The disease was multifocal in 17 patients. Appendicular skeleton was involved in 19 patients: tibia, femur, humerus and radius were primarily affected, mainly at the metaphyseal sites. Involvement of epiphysis or diaphysis was rare. Axial skeleton, mostly clavicle and spine, was involved in 8 patients. Radiographs and CT demonstrated the typical pattern of combined osteolysis and osteosclerosis in half of the study group. In the other half, osteosclerosis only or osteolysis was present. Hyperostosis was a common finding. MRI showed in all patients bone marrow oedema and adjacent soft tissue edema was frequent. No abcess formation was seen. Whole-body-MRI (STIR sequences) was always more contributive than scintigraphy to detect metaphyseal abnormalities. Conclusion Imaging patterns in CRMO are quite characteristic. However, atypical features deserve attention and whole-body-MRI seems very pertinent to detect silent lesions.
Bony and pulmonary eosinophilic granuloma: CT evidence of lesion evolution C Lanza, G Pieroni, V Bolli, B Fabrizzi, G Fabrizzi Azienda Ospedaliero-Universitaria Ospedali Riuniti, Italy
Background Eosinophilic granuloma (EG) is the most common and benign form of a rare proliferative disorder: Langerhans' cell histiocytosis. It commonly affects children.

Objective To present the clinical features, radiographic findings and management of 7 pediatric patients with bony and pulmonary EG. Materials and methods Between 2002 and 2008, 7 patients who initially presented with localized pain and soft tissue swelling or stiffness of the back were admitted to our hospital. Bone radiographs, CT scans of the involved bone and in 4 cases MRI too, were performed. All had chest CT and bone biopsy. The scans were repeated at intervals of six/ eight months. Results There were 5 boys and 2 girls (mean age: 8 years; range 3-14). Radiographs and CT bone scans revealed bony destruction or lytic lesions localized: in first metatarsal (1), in pelvis (2), in spine (1 cervical and 1 lumbar vertebra), in sternum (1) and femore (1). Four patients had association of bony lesion with extended asymptomatic pulmonary involvement: chest CT scans showed nodular lesions and thin-walled cysts, but the nodular lesions disappeared or were transformed into cystic lesions in the later scans. Most of the final scans revealed thin-walled cysts and emphysematous lesions. Histological examination of the bone biopsy showed features of eosinophilic granuloma with aggregates of Langerhans histiocytes. Conclusion EG is a rare intrinsically benign disease producing a destructive tumor with a variable clinical presentation and an often unpredictable clinical course . Bone involvement is generally observed in children mostly boys. Chest radiography and CT findings of EG are characteristic and vary with the stage. The lung disease led to the initial diagnosis and optimal surgical, pathological and radiological management.

Background Glutaric aciduria Type 1 (GA-1) is a recessively inherited inborn error of metabolism characterized by the deficiency of the mitochondrial enzyme Glutaryl CoA dehydrogenase (GCDH) which catalyzes the dehydrogenation-decarboxylation of Glutaric acid, an intermediary metabolite in the degradation pathway of lysine, hydroxy-lysine and tryptophan. Bitemporal arachnoid cysts and macrocephaly are the most common features of infants and children with GA-1. Objective To review the imaging features of GA-1 in a group of seven child patients. Materials and methods Clinical history and findings and brain MRI, proton magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS) and diffusionweighted imaging (DWI) results in 7 patients were reviewed. Results The most common clinical presentation was encephalitis-like episode. Age at the time of the diagnosis ranged between 6 and 24 months. Male to female ratio was 2/5. In all the patients macrocephaly, brain atrophy or hypoplasia, white matter changes, open opercula (usually very widely open), and wide cerebrospinal fluid spaces anterior to the temporal lobes were present. Basal ganglia lesions, presenting as volume loss and high T2 signal intensity in the lentiform nucleus bilaterally, were found in 100%. In one of the patients bilateral subdural hemorrhages were demonstrated. The MRS showed decreased N-acetyl-aspartate (NAA)/creatine (Cr) ratio and increase in choline (Cho)/Cr ratio. In addition, there was prominent lactate (lac) peak at 1.33 ppm. In DWI, we observed widespread restricted diffusion in the white matter and increased diffusion in bilateral putamen. Conclusion The finding of very widely open opercula suggests GA-1, and if combined with basal ganglia lesions is almost pathognomonic, especially in a child with macrocephaly. While conventional MR imaging plays an important role in determination of morphologic changes, functional information in areas of the brain involved can be provided by proton MRS and DWI.

The role of MR-imaging in children with primary solid tumors and CNS hematogenous brain metastasis L Porto, A Jarisch, M Kieslich, FE Zanella, R Du Mesnil Klinikum der Johann Wolfgang Goethe-Universität, Germany

Objective To characterize the incidence and MR-findings of haematogenous brain metastases among children with solid tumours. Materials and methods Among 429 patients with solid tumors during the period of 10 years, 4 eventually developed brain metastases. Patients with lesions secondary to direct extension from the skull or dura were excluded. MR characteristics studied of the brain metastasis included location, signal intensity, enhancement pattern, the presence of intratumoral haemorrhage, as well as the presence of secondary hydrocephalus or leptomeningeal spread. Results Of the 429 children with solid malignant tumors included in this study, 4 (0,9%) developed solitary brain metastasis. The solid primary tumours were nonsmall cell lung carcinoma, Wilm's tumour, Osteosarcoma und Hepatoblastoma. The mean time from initial diagnosis to the detection of brain metastases was 8, 5 months. All patients but one-nonsmall cell lung carcinoma-had known lung metastases. Brain metastases in children can have different sizes (mean size: 14 mm) and show perifocal oedema when associated with bleeding. All tumours were subcortical/cortical based and isointense with grey matter on unenhanced T1-weighted images and in two cases mildly hyperintense on T2-weighted images. Two patients showed restriction on diffusion-weighted images (DWI). Three out of 4 patients showed enhancement; two nodular-and one ringenhancement. In the patient with osteosarcoma the metastasis was calcified. Conclusion Solitary brain metastasis was the rule with variable MRcharacteristics. Although brain metastases are rare in children, they have grave prognosis. But CNS metastasis is not in itself a terminal event; metastasis in patients with Wilm's tumor might behave differently. We suggest MR routine imaging studies as part of metastases screening and by the time of tumor recurrence, especially in patients with solid tumors and recurrent or prior lung metastasis, even if the child shows no neurological changes. Background Foci of altered signal intensity (FASI) are the most common CNS involvement in neurofibromatosis von Recklinghausen type1. Progression of FASI during childhood, followed by their regression after puberty had been described previously. Objective The aim was to follow progression/ regression of FASI in NF1 in different age groups and different brain structures. Materials and methods Authors retrospectively evaluated development of FASI on the brain MRI in 200 NF1 patients. Groups of patients were defined according to patients age in time of examination. Groups of patients were imaged during childhood (below 10 years), between childhood and puberty, during puberty (10-14 years), between puberty and juvenile age and after puberty (more than 14 years). Results FASI involved 165/200 (82.5%) NF1 patients, 126 of them were followed up. Progression/regression ratio of FASI was 79/100 during childhood, 23/46 between childhood and puberty, 32/27 during puberty, 11/56 between puberty and juvenile age and 12/46 during juvenile age. Conclusion Regression of FASI prevails from the first examination during childhood till puberty and it is even accentuated after puberty. Progression of FASI was seen only during puberty.

Pictorial essay of neurocutaneous melanosis-Experience in a paediatric hospital Leysia Chu, Manohar Shroff, Charles Raybaud The Hospital for Sick Children Background Neurocutaneous melanosis is a rare phakomatoses of the skin and leptomeninges.

Objective To review MR findings of neurocuatneous melanosis; to evaluate whether multiplicity of skin lesion is a risk factor for CNS involvement Materials and methods MRI of all patients with diagnosis of giant/ multiple congenital melanocytic naevi referred for evaluation of CNS involvement in a paediatric hospital were retrieved for detailed review. Retrospective chart review was performed to examine the extent of cutaneous involvement. Multiplicity was defined as presence of 3 or more cutaneous naevi in physical examination. CNS involvement was defined as abnormal T1 hyperintensities and/or leptomeningeal enhancement in MRI brain or spinal cord using a 1.5 Tesla magnet. Other associated findings were documented. Results A total of 25 complete MRI studies of neuraxis were available for review in the imaging database. There were 16 males and 9 females, age ranged from 5 days to 13 years old (median= 9 months old). Twelve of the 25 patients had CNS involvement, among those 9 had multiple naevi. For those with only 1 or 2 pigmented naevi, only 3 out of 13 had CNS involvement. Three patients had T1 hyperintense lesions in the brain, 4 patients had leptomeningeal enhancement in spinal cord, 3 had leptomeningeal enhancement in brain and spinal cord. Two other patients had both T1 hyperintense lesions in the brain and leptomeningeal enhancement in the spinal cord. Chi square test showed a highly significant association between multiplicity of skin lesions and CNS involvement (6.74, p value of 0.009 with 99% C.I.). Conclusion MR imaging is an essential part of the evaluation for patients with giant/multiple congenital melanocytic naevi. Limited set of patients with multiple skin lesions appear to have a 3-fold increase in risk for neurocutaneous melanosis. This further supports and estimated the relative risk of CNS involvement. Background Prader Willi (PWS) is a very rare genetic disorder characterized by hyperphagia, obesity, small stature and learning difficulties. Posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES) is a clinicalneuroradiological entity, potentially reversible and usually presenting with acute or subacute headache, altered mental status, vomiting, seizures, and occipital lobe related symptoms. Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) shows: cortical and subcortical white matter edema of the parieto-occipital lobes, and other cerebral structures, such as the basal ganglia, frontal lobes, cerebellum, and brainstem. Acquired tonsil herniation, so-called "acquired Chiari I", may occur secondary to CSF hypotension, raised intracranial pressure (IP) or venous hypertension (VH). Case report A 7 year-old-boy, with a history of PWS, hyperthophicdilatative cardiomyopathy, arterious hypertension and renal cystic dysplasia, presented with asthenia, headache and extreme blood hypertension (BH). On admission, a brain CT showed small ventricles, multiple and symmetric hypodense cortical and subcortical areas, involving both of the cerebral hemispheres. The MR showed multiple areas of T2 hyperintesity and corresponding T1 hypointensity, prevailingly subcortical but also involving the cortex. The MRA and MRV were normal. DWI showed vasogenic, rather than cytoxic edema. The cerebellum was less affected but, likely due to raised IP, downward displacement of the cerebellar tonsils into the foramen magnum was evident. The child underwent a suboccipital decompression. The follow up MRI showed complete resolution imaging abnormalities. Clinical and imaging manifestations reversibility confirmed the diagnosis of PRES secondary to acute high blood pressure. Discussion and conclusion To our knowledge, we first describe a case of PRES in PWS with associated cerebellar tonsil herniation requiring urgent decompression. In absence of a previously diagnosed Chiari malformation, we can suppose that brain edema, observed during acute BH, resulted in ICH and tonsil herniation. Pathophysiology of PRES, particularly in the presented case, is debated.

Proton MR spectroscopy in the evaluation of functional and structural reorganization of brain in children with cerebral palsy-Initial report Background The injury of the connections between the cortex and other parts of the central nervous system leads to the physical disability of cerebral palsy patients. Thanks to the plasticity of the brain rehabilitation may cause reorganization of the cerebral cortex thus enabling clinical improvement. Objective To present the results of 1HMRS in children with cerebral palsy as a basis for evaluation of brain reorganization after one year of rehabilitation. Materials and methods Material consists of 56 children (34 m, 22f), aged 2,2-15,7 years, divided into 5 subgroups: (1) right-(n= 11) and (2) left (n = 7) hemiplegia, (3) diplegia (n = 19), (4) quadriplegia (n=14), (5) other/unclasified (n=5). Control group consists of 61 children (33 m, 28 f), aged 1,5-18,2 years. So far six children have been examined after 1 year of rehabilitiation. Nacetyloaspartate, choline and myoinositol ratios to creatine were obtained symmetrically in the cortex of frontal lobe, frontal operculum, temporo-occipital junction and in the basal ganglia. Statistical analysis was performed using Mann-Whitney, t-Student and Wilcoxon tests (p<0.05). Results Comparison of the ratios was performed in the analyzed group between the right and left hemisphere. This group was also compared to the control group. The most statistically significant differences were found in: 1) the NAA/Cr ratios, 2) the clinical group 4, 3) the basal ganglia. In the follow-up examinations no increase in NAA/Cr ratio has been found so far. Conclusion Statistically significant differences between analyzed and control group were the most pronounced in clinical subgroup 4. This may reflect the most severe brain injury in this group in our material. Paradoxically these differences were found mostly in the basal ganglia and not as expected in the cerebral cortex. Obtained initial results do not indicate the expected spectroscopic improvement in the rehabilitated patients and require further analysis in bigger material.

Neonatal spinal ultrasound: Normal appearances and pictorial review of pathologies encountered S Stafrace, KA Duncan Royal Aberdeen Children's Hospital Background Spinal Ultrasound is the first line investigation in infants suspected of having congenital abnormalities of the cord at birth. Objective To illustrate the range of normal appearances of the spine at birth and provide a pictorial review of the spectrum of abnormalities encountered. Materials and methods Cases referred to our institution for spinal ultrasound over the last 5 years were reviewed. Results As well as the normal range of findings, abnormal entities which will be illustrated include tethered cord, abnormal filum terminale, dorsal dermal sinus, meningocoele, myelocystocele, diastomatomyelia, hydromelia, and sacrococcygeal teratoma. Conclusion Our exhibit will help provide familiarity with normal and abnormal appearances encountered on spinal ultrasound.

Background There is an increasing demand for MR imaging of the paediatric ear structures in children with deafness, speech and language developmental delay and phonological disorders. In addition to the assessment of the inner ear structures, we provide a full set of three separate sequences and orthogonal planar assessment of the brain. Objective To determine if a full set of brain imaging should be an essential part of the MR imaging of the paediatric inner ear structures. Materials and methods A retrospective review of MR examinations of the paediatric inner ear structures over a 12-month period (June 2007-May 2008) was performed. The indications for the examinations, scanning technique, and abnormal radiological findings were analysed. In the case of a brain parenchymal abnormality, the sequence on which it was most apparent was also recorded. Results There were 22 patients (aged 1-14 years, mean 7.5 years; 15 males: 7 females). The main indications are sensori-neural hearing loss with14 patients (63.6%) and phonologic disorder with developmental delay 2 (9%). All patients had structurally normal inner ear, 6 (27.3%) had brain parenchymal abnormality of which 5 (22.7%) were significant and 1 (4.5%) was a normal variant. Of the 14 patients with sensori-neural hearing loss, 2 (14.3%) showed periventricular leucomalacia, 12 (85.7%) had no brain parenchymal abnormality. The other significant parenchymal findings are congenital cytomegalovirus infection, not specified leucodystrophy and neurofibromatosis. Conclusion A full set of brain imaging should not be an essential part of the assessment of the paediatric inner ear structures.
