body_text.text: Interest of MRI in the prenatal detection of associated brain anomalies in fetuses diagnosed with isolated cleft lip with or without cleft palate Mn De Milly, N Belarbi, E Vuillard, P Oger, Jf Oury, M Elmaleh, G Sebag Hopital Robert Debre

Objective To determine the interest of a systematical MRI to detect associated brain anomalies in fetuses diagnosed with isolated cleft lip with or without cleft palate. Materials and methods Retrospective study of 91 cases of fetuses prenatally diagnosed facial with cleft lip with or without palate, between 1993 and 2008. .Absence of associated anomaly was checked by ultrasound performed by a trained specialist. Brain MRI was done systematically. Were differentiated fetuses with isolated cleft lip from cleft lip with cleft palate, and unilateral from bilateral forms. The cleft and its type were checked after birth. Results Significant associated brain anomalies were detected by MRI, in 2 of the 80 cases selected after ultrasound. One case was a fetus with a unilateral cleft lip with cleft palate and the other case was a bilateral cleft lip with cleft palate. Conclusion The interest of performing a MRI after normal ultrasound is proved. But 2 in 80 cases is not significant statistically. To perform a systematical MRI is a choice.

Imaging in paediatric epilepsy-A pictorial review V Godhamgaonkar 1 , S Harave 1 , R Harrison 2 1. Royal Liverpool Children's Hospital NHS Trust, Alder Hey, Liverpool 2. Queen Alexandra Hospital, Portsmouth Hospitals NHS Trust, Portsmouth

Background Diagnosing and treating paediatric epilepsy is challenging. We present a comprehensive pictorial review of various etiologies presenting as seizures or epilepsy in children. Although imaging is not routinely indicated following a simple febrile convulsion, it is vital in the assessment of children with a focal neurological deficit, developmental delay, neurocutaneous syndromes, simple and refractory complex partial seizures etc. Objectives After reviewing this poster, the delegates will be able to-1. Enumerate various pathologic conditions manifesting as seizures and their imaging findings. 2. Discuss the role of MRI in diagnosing structural abnormalities in paediatric epilepsy. Materials and methods We have attempted to include MR imaging of wide spectrum of disorders presenting as acute onset seizures with neurological symptoms such as infection, hemorrhage, tumour, suspected NAI etc. We have emphasized the crucial role of detailed MRI examination to reveal structural abnormalities in chronic seizure disorders or refractory epilepsy. Temporal lobe epilepsy, mesial temporal sclerosis and focal cortical dysplasia are some such entities. We have included a brief pictorial description of various developmental disorders e.g. scizencephaly, polymicrogyria, hemimegalencephaly etc., neurocutaneous syndromes, metabolic disorders, congenital infections, hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy etc. A few of the childhood neoplasms like DNET, giant cavernoma etc. have been included. To conclude, we have briefly touched upon the role of SPECT and PET, functional MRI and spectroscopy etc. in the imaging work up of patients with option of possible curative surgery. Conclusion We intend to provide the delegates a pleasant learning experience through this well presented, educational pictorial tour.

The value of the color doppler ultrasonography in differentiation of benign subarachnoid spaces dilatation from subdural collection in infants Xinyu Yuan, Yingzi Su Capital Institute of Pediatrics, China

Background It is important to differentiate the benign subarachnoid spaces from subdural collection in children Objective To differentiate the benign subarachnoid spaces dilatation from subdural collection in infants with color Doppler US. Materials and methods 27 case with paricerebral fluid collection were reviewed retrospectively. Among them, 14 cases with purulent meningitis were confirmed as subdural collection by subdural centesis and 13 patients with benign subarachnoid spaces dilatation diagnosed by MR. Color Doppler US images of these patients were reviewed focus on the inner margin and distribution of collections and vascular sign. Results In the group of subdural collection (14 cases), 10 (71.4%) were unilateral and 4 were bilateral. On the contrast, only 1 cases (7.6%) with benign subarachnoid spaces dilatation was unilateral. Nearly almost (12/14, 85.7%) cases of sudural collections had smooth inner margin and 13 cases (100%) with benign subarachnoid spaces dilatation showed irregular, gyre-like inner margin. Vascular sign was seen in all enlarged subarachnoid spaces, but there was no cases with subdural effusion could be found the appearence. Conclusion Color Doppler US is an noninvasive, critical tool to differentiate the benign subarachnoid spaces dilatation from subdural collection in infants.

Brain CT appearances of febrile seizures in children Xinyu Yuan, Yang Yang Capital Institute of Pediatrics, China Background There were less repots about the imaging findings of febrile convulsions in children.

Objective To evaluate the appearances of brain CT of children with febrile seizures, and assess the value of brain CT in child febrile convulsions. Materials and methods Brain CT images of 334 cases with febrile seizures were reviewed retrospectively. Among them, there were 211 boys and 123 girls, aged from 10 days to 7 years old. The patients in our study were divided into tow groups depend on their age. Group A, children less than 1 year old, and group B was comprised of children greater than 1 year old. The appearance of brain CT were analyzed focus on paricerebral spaces dilatation and other intracranial abnormalities. Results In our study, there were 220 cases (65.9%) could be found abnormal appearances on their brain CT. Enlarged paricerebral spaces were seen in 192 cases (59.3%), 48 cases (48/52, 92.3%) in group A and 150 cases (150/282, 53.2%) in group B. There are significant differences in visualization rate and severities of paricerebral spaces dilatation between the groups statistically. Otherwise, there were mega cisterna magna (11, 3.3%), ventricular enlargement (10, 3%) , arachnoid cysts (6, 1.8%), calcification (3, 0.9%), septum pellucidum cysts (2, 0.6%) and reduced white matter volume (2, 0.6%). Conclusion The major appearance in brain CT of children with febrile seizures is enlarged paricerebral spaces represented immature of brains. Not all patients with febrile convulsions need CT examination.

The value of diffusion magnetic resonance imaging in patients with cured acute lymphoblastic leukemia Melda Apaydin, Emine Dilek 1 , Canan Vergin 1 , Aysegul Sarsilmaz, Makbule Varer, Gulten Coskun, Melike Bedel Koruyucu 1. Izmir Ataturk Egitim ve Arastırma Hastanesi Radyoloji Anabilim Dalı Izmir Behcet Uz Egitim ve Arastırma Hastanesi Cocuk Hematoloji Bilim Dalı, Turkey

Objective White matter lesions are the most common neurologic complications found on MR imaging that may be related to cranial irradiation, agressive chemotherapy and intrathecal methotrexate (MTX) therapy in childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). We aimed to document the radiologic abnormalities seen in the central nervous system (CNS) after treatment of childhood leukemia with MR imaging using standart and diffusion MR protocols. We aimed to show the advantage of diffusion MR to cranial MR. Materials and methods MR images of 29 patients with ALL were examined. Images were aquired by a 1.5 T MR by using T1-weighted, T2-weighted spin echo, and fluid-attenuated inversion recovery sequences and diffusion MRI . All of the patients were treated according to TRALL protocol. Seven ( 24%) of them were in high, 19 (65%) of them were in medium, 15 (51%) of them were low risk group. None of them have any acute neurological disorder. Results Twenty seven patient had no abnormality on cranial and diffusion MR. Two patients had abnormal findings. One of them had milimetric hemorrhagic brain lesion on cranial and diffusion MR. Another patient had chronic brain lesion due to previous meningitis on two different technique. Conclusion The CNS abnormalities that occur after the treatment of leukemia are related to the leukemia itself, to the treatment method, and to the duration of survival. Because many neurologic complications of leukemia are treatable, early diagnosis is essential. There was no positive impact of diffusion MR technique on cured ALL patients who did not have any acute neurological symptoms. But we can conclude that adding this modality in acute neurologic symptomatology may show some positive impact to the treatment by detecting acute ischemic changes due to venous brain infarcts.

Central skull base osteomyelitis in children: Presentation, imaging and complications R Singaroyan, S Rajaram, D Connolly, A Raghavan Sheffield Children's Hospital, Royal Hallamshire Hospital, UK Background Skull base osteomyelitis (SBO) arising from sphenoidal paranasal air sinus infection without associated otitis is rare. Diagnosis relies heavily on imaging as presentation can be insidious with headache being the only feature with cranial neuropathies or long tract signs only developing later. Early diagnosis and treatment can prevent disability Objective To review the clinical and imaging features of central skull base osteomyelitis with an emphasis on MR imaging. Materials and methods We reviewed the clinical presentation, complications, CT and MR imaging in four patients with central skull base osteomyelitis. No patient had predisposing otitis media of the temporal bone. Results Clinical presentations were varied. Complications included lateral medullary syndrome, cavernous sinus thrombosis, epidural abscesses and cranial neuropathies. CT features showed no changes or very mild bone lucency with paranasal sinus opacification. The most consistent MR imaging findings were clival and petrous apex bone marrow T1 hypointensity which showed improvement following antibiotic treatment. Post gadolinium T1 fat saturation imaging was also useful to demonstrate dural enhancement and the extent of any associated soft tissue phlegmon. Conclusion Although a rare condition , knowledge of the imaging features of skull base osteomyelitis is vital in order to facilitate early diagnosis. Early intervention with appropriate treatment may then prevent or limit further complications such as intracranial extension, empyema, or death. Background Sjögren-Larsson syndrome (SLS) is a neurocutaneous syndrome caused by a genetic deficiency of fatty aldehyde dehydrogenase (FALDH) enzyme in lipid metabolism, inherited as an autosomal recessive trait. It is characterized by congenital ichthyosis, mental retardation, and spastic diplegia or tetraplegia. Accumulation of long-chain fatty alcohol which is detectable by chemical-shift analysis is thought to be responsible for the cutaneous and neurologic symptoms of SLS. Objective Our purpose was to characterize the cerebral involvement in SLS and to demonstrate its Magnetic Resonance imaging (MRI) and MR Spectroscopy findings. Materials and methods A 7-year and a 2-year old male, both with ichthyosis, mental retardation, and spastic diplegia, were assessed with MRI and MR Spectroscopy. Also various biochemical tests were used to identify any enzymatic deficiency. Results MRI showed periventricular lesions, low intensity on T1weighted images and high intensity on T2-weighted images at trigones of the lateral ventricles in both patients. In the first patient white matter of the frontal lobes were also involved according to late stage of the disease. 1H-MRS of these lesions in both patients revealed high lipid and low N-acetyl aspartate peaks. Fatty alcohol oxidoreductase (FAO) deficiency that is specific for Sjögren-Larsson Syndrome (SLS) has been verified biochemically. Conclusion SLS is a rare lipid metabolism disorder and should be kept in mind for the differential diagnosis of the cases with demyelination in the periventricular white matter and lipid peaks in 1H-MRS. Background An aberrant development of the branchial apparatus (BA) results in a spectrum of anomalies that includes fistulas, sinuses, cysts and craniofacial malformations.

The most common complication of the BA anomalies is infection. The definitive treatment of the BA anomalies is the surgical excision. Objective 1.To review the imaging findings of the BA anomalies in children. 2. To discuss the differential diagnosis with other head and neck pediatric entities. Materials and methods We reviewed all the cases of BA anomalies seen at our Institution. With the aim of reaching a better understanding, we review the embryogenesis of the branchial apparatus and its anatomical implications. We illustrate the differential diagnosis showing examples of mimicking entities. Results We present a pictorial review of the different BA subtypes and their main differential diagnosis. Most branchial anomalies involve the first and second clefts.

First BA anomalies usually present as a cyst, sinus, or fistula somewhere between the external auditory canal and the submandibular area. Second BA anomalies typically result in a fistula or cyst in the lower, anterolateral region of the neck. Third BA anomalies present in a similar way. Fourth BA anomalies are rare. We include cases of the Goldenhar syndrome, a craniofacial malformation related to a BA anomaly. US, CT and MRI were used for the imaging diagnosis. We present also cases diagnosed with fistulography, done through the skin opening of the fistula. Mimicking entities mainly include parotid and thymic cysts, lymphatic malformations, suppurative lympadenitis, neck abscesses and thyroglossal duct cysts. Conclusion The branchial apparatus anomalies may represent a diagnostic challenge for the Pediatric Radiologist. A full understanding of their embryonic origin is crucial.

Uspio-enhanced MRI after intraperitoneal injection of ferumoxtran-10 in newborn rats: A new tool for pediatric research O Prodhomme, R Azoulay, L Schwendimann, R Santus, P Robert, G Sebag Hospital Robert Debré, Paris, France

Background Ferumoxtran-10 (Ultrasmall Superparamagnetic Particles of Iron Oxides, USPIO) is a new magnetic resonance contrast agent witch enhances macrophages when it is injected intravenously. The effectiveness to enhance macrophages, of an intrapertioneal injection of ferumoxtran-10, has been recently described (neonatal rats, high dose [2,400µmol/Kg]). Objective The purpose of our study was the optimization of injected dose as low as possible with the objective of 300µmol/Kg (adult animal studies). Materials and methods After a pilot study (n=27), 111 newborn rats were killed, after a saline injection or after intra-peritoneal injection of 300µmol/Kg Ferumoxtran-10 (from 2 hours to 6 days after injection), in order to measure iron concentration into either peritoneal fluid (n= 26) or plasma samples (n=85 [63 + 22] ). Intracellular iron uptake in liver, spleen, bone marrow, kidney and brain was assessed using Perl's stain (n=63). The density of Prussian blue labeled cells was quantified.

The signal time course of liver, spleen and bone marrow was studied in vivo on a 1,5 T MR system using a dedicated surface coil (n=22). Proton density-weighted sequences were used. Results Ferumoxtran-10 was rapidly absorbed from peritoneum. A peak of plasma iron concentration is obtained 8 h after injection. It raises a value in the range of the plasma iron concentration after an IV injection of 40µmol/Kg. Forty-eight hours after injection no Ferumoxtran-10 remained in plasma. Statistically significant negative enhancement of the liver, spleen and bone marrow was measured in correlation with the Ferumoxtran-10 plasma concentration and its cellular uptake. Conclusion Intra-peritoneal injection of 300µmol/Kg Ferumoxtran-10 in newborn rats is safe, reproducible and effective to enhance macrophages in MRI. The pharmacokinetic profile observed promises perfusion imaging applications (short delay post-injection) and macrophage imaging applications (long delay).

Phase-contrast cine MR imaging in evaluation of communication between intraventricular arachnoid cysts and neighboring CSF spaces in 11 pediatric case O Algin, G Gokalp, Z Yazici Radiology Department, Medical Faculty, Uludag University, Bursa, Turkey

Background Arachnoid cysts (ACs) are classified as communicating or non-communicating according to their relation to the neighboring cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) spaces. Inadequate or non-existent communication between the cyst and the neighboring CSF spaces seems to be responsible for mass effect and progressive symptoms. Therefore, demonstration of communication between AC and the adjacent CSF space is often required if surgical therapy is contemplated. Objective To evaluate the role of phase-contrast cine MR imaging (PC-MRI) in detecting possible communications between intraventricular ACs (IV-ACs) and CSF spaces based on comparison with MR cisternography (MRC) in pediatric cases. Materials and methods The study group was consisted of 11 pediatric patients with IV-AC (age range, 6 months-10 years; mean age, 6 years) underwent PC-MRI followed by MRC after intratechal injection of 0.5 ml gadopentetate dimeglumine. The results were statistically analyzed by using the McNemar test. Results According to the MRC results, of 11 IV-ACs 6 were noncommunicating and 5 communicating. PC-MRI results were compatible with MRC findings in 8 patients. The sensitivity and specificity of PC-MRI imaging in demonstrating the communication between the IV-ACs and the CSF were 100% and 50%, respectively (PPV: 63%, NPV: 100%). Conclusion Our results show that PC-MRI is a reliable method for identifying of non-communicating IV-ACs. However, any positive result for communication between an IV-AC and neighboring CSF spaces on PC-MRI should be encountered with suspicion. Background SBS frequently leads to death or severe morbidity. Inflicted circumstances are unknown at the time of the diagnosis. To date, signs of SBS are well described but their frequency is not specified.

Objective To provide an iconographic review including the frequency of each imaging pattern. To discuss pitfalls. Materials and methods Retrospective study (2003) (2004) (2005) (2006) (2007) (2008) including 73 patients with subdural hematoma on CT and medico-legal conclusions including revelations. The full clinical, biological, imaging data were analyzed. Results The series includes 76% of males, 75% under 6 months. Eigthy percent of patients were admitted for hypotonia or coma with seizures. Twenty-three percent of patients died. The location of the subdural hematoma was: fronto-parietal (92%) often bilateral (66%), interhemispheric (90%) and cerebellar falx (90%). Two localisations at least were almost constant (99%). The vertex was frequently involved (81%). Parenchymal abnormalities were seen on CT in 53% of patients and MRI was always more accurate.

The rate of fractures was low: skull (11%) , ribs (14%), metaphysis (17%). Retinal hemorrhages were not constant (85%) and sometimes unilateral (7%). Ecchymosis (45%) were located at the sites of grabbing.

Finally, in only 5% of patients, the subdural hematoma was not associated to either retinal hemorrhages, cutaneous or skeletal injuries. Early CT control (day 1-3, n=24) often disclosed an increase of the hemorrhage which helped to confirm the diagnosis of SBS in doubtful cases.

The datation is not precise. Hyperacute hematomas are heterogeneous and density of chronic hematomas may spontaneously modify. Thereby, the diagnosis of age-different hematomas should take into account two different locations. Conclusion Two sites at least of subdural hematoma are almost constant in SBS. The analysis of the vertex is one clue. Background Hemophagocytic lymphohisticytosis (HLS), also called hemophagocytic syndrome, is a rare multisystem immune disorder characterized with aggressive proliferation of activated macrophages and histiocytes. Secondary HLS is much more common than the primary disease. Almost all patients die following occurrence of multiple relapses or central nervous system disease progression. Objective To evaluate cranial imaging features of HLS and define the frequency and severity of the lesions. Materials and methods The clinical and radiologic data of 9 infants diagnosed as primary HLS in Erciyes University, Gevher Nesibe Hospital between May 2005 and January 2009 have been retrospectively analyzed. All patients had cranial CT and/or contrast-enhanced MR imaging. The images were interpreted by two pediatric radiologists independently. Results All patients (5 girls, 4 boys) presented with convulsion except 2 patients who had hemiparesis and tremor of the upper extremity. The prognosis was poor that 8 of the 9 patients died during follow-up. One patient, who was alive, was recently diagnosed and under therapy. The imaging findings were normal in 5 patients. The most common finding was T2-prolongation of cerebral white matter that was seen 4 patients. Cerebellar white matter was also involved in 3 patients. There were lesions in brain stem in 2 patients. There were corticospinal tract involvement in 1 patient and laminar necrosis in 1 patient. There were multiple nodular lesions in the cerebrum and cerebellum with ring enhancement in 1 patient and without ring enhancement in the other. Diagnostic value of CT was significantly lower than MR imaging. Conclusion Primary HLS may have characteristic cranial MRI features. Radiologists should be aware of the characteristic MRI findings which can be used as a supplementary diagnostic modality to clinical and laboratory findings of HLS. Results The mean age of the study group was 5.7 years (range, 1-15 years) including 19 boys and 13 girls. Ten patients had history of upper airway infection and 6 had history of gastroenteritis prior to the onset of the disease. The mean duration of the symptoms was 5.5 days (range, 2-22 days) and the mean recovery time was 7.5 days (range, 3-21 days). Twenty patients had electromyogram and 18 of them revealed findings consistent with GBS. Twenty-nine patients had albumino-cytologic dissociation. Thirty patients were treated with IVIG, and 2 with plasmapheresis. All but 2 patients had thickening and contrast enhancement of nerve roots and cauda equina on spinal MRI. The enhancement was mild in 13 patients, moderate in 12 patients, and severe in 5 patients. Seventeen patients had cranial MRI in addition to spinal MRI and they did not reveal any abnormality although 2 of them had unilateral 6th cranial nerve paralysis. Conclusion Contrast-enhanced spinal MRI is a reliable imaging for the diagnosis of GBS that it was positive in 30 of 32 of our patients. Imaging features of late-type vitamin K deficiency bleeding Ali Yikilmaz 1 , Musa Karakukcu 2 , Selim Doganay 1 , Ekrem Unal 2 , Turkan Patiroglu 2 , Mehmet Akif Ozdemir 2 , Abdulhakim Coskun 1 1. Department of Radiology, School of Medicine, Erciyes University 2. Department of Pediatric Hematology, School of Medicine, Erciyes University Background Vitamin K deficiency, causing bleeding in infant period of life, known as hemorrhagic disease of the newborn (HDN) is divided into three categories: early, classic and late HDN. Early HDN occurs within 24 h, classic HDN occurs on days one to seven; common bleeding sites are gastrointestinal, cutaneous. Late HDN occurs from week 2 to 12; and may be associated with serious and life-threatening intracranial hemorrhage that can be detected with cranial imaging. Objective We discuss the cranial imaging features of late HDN and draw attention to the importance of prophylaxis, early diagnosis and adequate treatment of late-type HDN, and we review the relevant literature. Materials and methods Data of 16 infants treated with late-type HDN in Erciyes University, Gevher Nesibe Hospital between June 2006 and December 2008 have been retrospectively analyzed. The images were interpreted by two radiologists independently and the radiological findings were correlated with neurological findings. Results The patients's (10 boys and 6 girls) ages varied from 31 days to 10 months (median 3 months). Twelve infants presented with irritability and convulsions, whereas 4 were admitted with complaints of bleeding from previous injections. Ten infants revealed neurological abnormalities including hypertonicity, hyperreflexia, and respiratory disorder. All patients were examined with cranial CT and 4 patients had cranial MRI in the late phase. Twelve of the 16 patients who presented with neurological abnormalities had intracranial hemorrhage and unilateral cerebral edema. Is neuroimaging necessary in children with primary headache? Abdulhakim Coskun, Ali Yikilmaz, Selim Doganay, Ertugrul Mavili, Ibrahim Sacit Tuna, Halil Donmez School of Medicine, Erciyes University, Kayseri, Turkey Background Headache is a common clinical problem during childhood. Materials and methods Thirty children (19 girls, 11 boys; age range, 6-15 years) with primary recurrent headache were prospectively evaluated with cranial CT (15 patients) or MRI (15 patients). In one patient, there was multiple, bilateral T2-hyperintense foci in cerebral white matter consistent with non specific white matter disease. In this patient, further clinical evaluation was suggested and imaging findings contributed to the patient management. Conclusion The vast majority of the cases had no abnormal neuroimaging findings that changed the patient management. Background Polymicrogyria is a malformation of cortical development with abnormal neuronal organisation. It results in multiple small gyri with an irregular grey-white matter junction. Many causes for polymicrogyria are recognised, including congenital infections and genetic syndromes. Objective We present the novel, characteristic MRI phenotype in three patients from two separate families. All patients have severe, generalised bilateral polymicrogyria. The corpus callosum is either absent or hypoplastic. The brainstem has a characteristic pontomedullary junction with a widened upper medulla. The tectum is prominent. Background and objective The origin of the association of the agenesis of the corpus callosum with interhemispheric cyst (ACC with IHC) is controversial and several systems have been proposed to classify this entity. We aimed to present five patients of ACC with IHC, and discuss different aspects from currently established classification system.

We analyzed the MRI findings of five patients (four males, one female; age 3 months to 16 years) with ACC with IHC. Results Our patient population included two Type 1c cysts, in which the cyst was in communication with the ventricle and three Type 2 cysts [type 2b (n=2), type 2c (n=1)], in which the cysts were not in communication with the ventricular system. High-resolution susceptibility weighted imaging as diagnostic tool for children HJ Mentzel, A Deistung, KH Hermann, M Waginger, HP Burmeister, JR Reichenbach Pediatric Radiology, University of Jena Background Susceptibility-weighted imaging (SWI) is becoming an increasingly used clinical method in neuroimaging MR protocols to study venous related cerebral pathologies and vascular malformations. Materials and methods We studied children with vasular malformations and different cerebral lesions on 1.5T MR units using standard head coils. A high-resolution 3D highly T2*-weighted gradient echo sequence with first-order flow compensation and radiofrequency spoiling was created for SWI. Magnitude and phase images were reconstructed. Results Using high-resolution SWI highly detailed information about the veins was obtained in all patients with vascular malformations. Differentiation of calcified lesions or hemorrhages was possible by using phase images. Conclusion In children high-resolution SWI may be of special importance in the early detection and assessment of vascular malformations and in the differential diagnosis of different tumor entities. Background Dyslexia is a neurobiological disease of reading and writing abilities. There were some volumetrical reports about structural differences between dyslectic and normal reading children in the area of the planum temporale, the gyrus angularis, and in the frontal lobe.

Materials and methods 12 dyslexic children (8 boys, 4 girls; age 13.3± 1.04 years) and 11 normal reading children (age and gender matched) were included. Polymicrogyria correlation of MRI and clinical findings Ertugrul Mavili, Abdulhakim Coskun, Ali Yikilmaz, Selim Doganay, Halil Donmez Medical Faculty, Erciyes University, Kayseri, Turkey

Background Polymicrogyria is a malformation of cortical development characterized by many small gyri separated by shallow sulci. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) has greatly facilitated the recognition of polymicrogyria. Although PMG can affect any portion of one or both hemispheres, the sylvian fissures are the most affected lobes. Mental retardation, seizures and motor mental disease are the most presenting clinical features. Objective To evaluate the correlation between clinical presentation and the extent of cortical involvement in patients with polymicrogyria. Materials and methods The MR findings of 26 patients were evaluated for the location and distribution of polymicrogyria. Presence of asphyxia at birth and serological tests for TORCH infections, the presence and type (spastic, flaccid) of motor deficits, mental development, microcephaly, and epilepsy were noted. Results 19 patients had bilateral whereas 7 had unilateral involvement. Patients with unilateral polymicrogyria presented later with milder symptoms. The most encountered symptom in patients with bilateral involvement was MMR (89%) and speech problems (84%). The clinical presentations of patients with asphyxia and positive serological tests for CMV were worse. All patients with positive serological tests for CMV had bilateral involvement. Perisylvian region was affected in 5 (71%) patients with unilateral involvement. The most encountered presenting symptom in these patients was epilepsy. Cerebral palsy was seen in three (43%) of the patients and all of them had left hemiparesis. Microcephaly, MMR and speech delay was detected in one (14%) of the patients. Conclusion Late presenting epilepsy may be a predictor of a unilateral polymicrogyria and is associated with relatively good prognosis. CMV infection and the presence of asphyxia are predictors of worse prognosis.
Magnetic resonance imaging findings in infantile meningoencephalitis J Bracken, S Walsh, S Ryan, VB Donoghue, ET Womey Children's Universtiy Hospital, Temple Street, Dublin

Background Meningoencephalitis can result in a number of serious complications affecting the developing infant brain. Identification of these complications plays an important role both in guiding patient management and assessing prognosis. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain is central to the radiological assessment of such patients. Objective To describe the range of magnetic resonance imaging features found in infantile meningoencephalitis due to a variety of microorganisms. Materials and methods A retrospective review was performed of the imaging findings in all infants with proven microbial meningitis/ meningoencephalitis who underwent MR Brain examination over a three-year period between January 2006 and January 2009. Results A total of 29 infants were identified during the study period, the majority (17) of whom were male. The age at presentation ranged from 11 days to 15 months with a median age of 15 weeks. Fourteen of the patients were neonates at presentation. A variety of organisms were identified as follows: gram positive bacteria (17 cases): S. pneumoniae, Group B Streptococci, Group D Streptococci; gram negative bacteria (8 cases): N. meningitidis, E. coli, Enterobacter, H. influenzae type B, Proteus; viral organisms (3 cases): Herpes simplex, Cytomegalovirus, Human Herpes Virus type 6 and one case of the protozoan Toxoplasmosis. All patients, with the exception of one, had acute abnormalities on initial MRI. Complications found on imaging included: oedema (12); infarction (11); ventricular dilatation (8); ventriculitis (6); infected porencephalic cysts (1); extra-axial fluid collections including subdural effusion (3), small subdural haematoma (2), extra-axial pus collection (4); pachygyria (1-Toxoplasmosis); periventricular calcification (1-Toxoplasmosis); polymicrogyria (1-Cytomegalovirus). Conclusion We found a wide variety of imaging abnormalities in infants with meningitis/meningoencephalitis ranging from more common findings such as infarction to rarer complications such as ventriculitis and subdural haematoma.

Pre-natal diagnosis and post-natal follow up of rapidly involuting congenital hemangioma (RICH) Michael F Fadell, Blaise V Jones, Denise Adams Cincinnati Children's Hospital, USA Background Congenital hemangiomas are recently classified neoplasms that are distinct from the more common capillary hemangiomas of infancy in that they are mature at birth. These uncommon lesions can be further divided into two distinct subcategories; rapidly involuting (RICH) or noninvoluting (NICH). Rapidly involuting congenital congenital hemangiomas (RICH) are more common, with the majority involuting completely by 12 months of age. Noninvoluting congenital hemangiomas (NICH) never involute, demonstrate proportional growth, and require eventual treatment with excision. Objective To demonstrate the clinical and imaging findings of an intracranial rapidly involuting congenital hemangioma (RICH). Materials and methods Pre and post-natal MRI, along with ultrasound, and computed tomography (CT) was used to identify and follow the anatomy, imaging characteristics, vascularity, and size of this intracranial lesion. Results We present the case of an intracranial, extra-axial, vascular lesion with an associated cutaneous component. Following intralesional hemorrhage, it demonstrated rapid involution within the first year of life. Conclusion This poster will present the salient imaging findings and clinical features of an intracranial rapidly involuting congenital hemangioma (RICH). We have found no prior reports of an intracranial rapidly involuting congenital hemangioma (RICH) in our review of the literature.

An MRI approach to the CNS inflammatory demyelinating disorders in children Monica Rebollo Polo, Eoghan E Laffan, Daniela Pohl, Hussein Nasser, Hazar Tabban, Julie Hurteau-Miller Children's Hospital of Eastern Ontario, Ottawa, Canada

Background CNS inflammatory demyelinating disorders of childhood include both self-limited and life-long conditions that can be difficult to differentiate clinically at the time of presentation.The identification and ddx of pediatric Multiple Sclerosis (MS) and other related demyelinating syndromes, such as ADEM (Acute Demyelinating Encephalomyelitis) or NMO (Neuromyelitis Optica), is a hot topic in the current Pediatric Neurology literature. Discussions focus on the importance of early differentiation of these disorders.MRI plays a major role in the diagnostic approach and monitoring of demyelinating disease. New MRI diagnostic criteria for pediatric MS have been recently proposed in the Pediatric Neurology literature. Objective To review the MRI findings of the CNS demyelinating disorders of the childhood, placing emphasis in their ddx. Materials and methods We describe the MRI findings of 13 the patients with demyelinating diseases seen at our Institution. We focus on the ddx between MS, ADEM and NMO in the context of the new international consensus definitions. We also place emphasis in the MS cases, according to the new MRI criteria proposed for pediatric MS. Results We review the MRI findings that are more typical of each entity (MS, ADEM,NMO). Periventricular lesions are more frequent in children with MS. A diffuse bilateral lesion pattern is more typical of ADEM. MS initial presentation can meet the diagnostic criteria of ADEM. Two patients initially diagnosed as ADEM were reclassified as MS. NMO affects the optic nerves and spinal cord. One patient with NMO also showed brain lesions, located in the hypothalamus and brainstem.

Conclusion MRI plays a major role in the diagnostic approach of demyelinating disorders. New MRI diagnostic criteria for pediatric MS have been recently proposed. The Pediatric Neuroradiologist should be aware of the new international consensus definitions proposed for pediatric MS and related disorders.
Typical CT findings of alobar holoprosencephaly Sacide Unel, Esra Coskuntuncel, Unal Egeli, Saban Odabasi Vakif Gureba Educational Hospital, Istanbul, Turkey

Background Holoprosencephaly is the most common forebrain defect in humans with a prevelance of 1:10.000 and 1:20.000 at birth. The holoprosencephalies are a group of disorders that are characterized by a failure of differantiation and cleavage of prosencephalon, and divided into three categories: alobar, semilobar and lobar. Alobar holoprosencephaly is the most severe form. Objective Altough alobar holoprosencephaly is the most common form of holoprosencephaly diagnosed by prenatal ultrasound, affected patients are rarely imaged by CT or MR postnatally. Thıs rarity probably stems from the fact that most affected infants are stillborn or have a very short lifespan . In this poster we report cranial BT images of an eight months aged baby who had typical findings of alobar holoprosencphaly. Materials and methods An eigth moths aged female baby with severe facial abnormalities (hypotelorizm, median lip and palate cleft, single nostril) and hypotonia admitted to our hospıtal because of epilepsy. After clinical examination a nonenhaced CT of the brain was performed. Results On the nonenhaced CT of the bran we observed a large thin layer of cortex around a large monoventricle with large dorsal cyst. No interhemispheric fissure, falx cerebri, third ventricle or corpus callosum could be identified. The thalami and basal ganglia were reduced in volume, fused and anteriorly placed. Conclusion Alobar holoprosencephaly is the most severe form, imaging studies are severely abnormal, as well. In affected patients, ventral medial portions of the brain never form. As a result the hypotalami and basal ganglia are fused and reduced in volume and the third ventricle is absent. Patient with alobar holoprosencephaly usually have severe midline facial deformities and hypotelorism, resulting from absence or hypoplasia of the premaxillary segment of the face . Imaging of the brain by CT or MRI confirms the diagnosis of holoprosencephaly, defines the subtype, and identifies associated CNS anomalies.

Traumatic herniation of buccal fat pad into the oral cavity with fat necrosis Bhairav Patel, Brandon Tran, Jill Hunter, Ellen Friedman Texas Children's Hospital, USA Background There is an extensive differential diagnosis for pediatric intraoral masses, though the demonstration of fat within a mass significantly limits the possibilities. A rare fat-containing mass within the pediatric oral cavity is discussed.

Objective To describe the pertinent CT imaging findings of a rare complication of pediatric oral trauma, herniation of buccal fat pad into the oral cavity. Case report 10 month old male who fell onto the right side of his face. The following day the patient had difficulty feeding and was found to have a soft, pedunculated intraoral mass arising from the right buccal mucosa. A contrasted CT of the neck was performed. On the basis of the CT findings the patient was taken to the operating room where a small defect within the buccal mucosa just posterior to the orifice of the parotid duct was found, from which the aforementioned mass protruded.

Results CT of the neck demonstrated a well-circumscribed 1.5 cm focus of fat attenuation with superimposed inflammatory changes, which was in direct contiguity with the ipsilateral buccal fat pad. No associated calcifications, maxillary osseous changes, or lymphadenopathy were present. Histological analysis of the resected intraoral mass demonstrated benign adipose tissue with superimposed fat necrosis. Conclusion The differential diagnosis for soft tissue masses within the pediatric oral cavity is rather extensive and includes granular cell tumors including congenital epulitides, rhabdomyomas, salivary gland tumors, venolymphatic malformations, ectopic thyroid tissue, traumatic granulomas, and fat-containing masses. Pediatric fat-containing intraoral masses would include dermoid cysts, tumors of adipose origin, or surgically placed fat for the correction of various oral cavity defects. In addition, though a relatively rare entity with less than forty case reports in the literature in the presence of antecedent trauma and fat-containing mass identified on imaging traumatically herniated buccal fat pad into the oral cavity should be considered.

Value of brain 1H-MR spectroscopy in pediatric patients with normal brain MRI Girish Kori, Hashim Hayder, Nicole Hauser, Andrea Gropman, Nadja Kadom, Gilbert Vezina George Washington University Medical Center

Background The utility of proton-MR spectroscopy (MRS) of the pediatric brain is well established for a variety of conditions (i.e. Canavan's, hyperglycinemia, leukodystrophy). However, there is little data on the overall utility of pediatric brain MRS in the setting of normal conventional MRI imaging. Objective Better defining clinical and imaging scenarios in which MRS will likely be diagnostic or supportive in diagnosis/therapy may help utilize this resource more effectively. We hypothesize that the diagnostic yield of MRS is lower in patients with otherwise normal conventional MRI (cMRI)findings, than in those with additional abnormalities on cMRI sequences. Materials and methods Retrospective analysis was performed of MRS studies completed October 1, 2007-September 30, 2008. The imaging results were documented separately for cMRI and MRS into 3 categories: "normal", "abnormal without contribution to diagnosis", and "abnormal with contribution to diagnosis". The coincidence of diagnostic outcomes between conventional MR and MRS was determined. Pictorial essay of typical cMRI/MRS findings is also presented. Results The total number of MRS studies performed over the 12 month period was 153. Overall, 50 MRI studies had a normal MRS in conjunction with a normal cMRI. In 41 studies, there was a normal MRS in conjunction with an abnormal cMRI. In 62 patients, both MRS and cMRI were abnormal; of these studies, MRS significantly contributed to making the diagnosis in 44 patients and was non-contributory in 18 cases. No studies were found in which the MRS was abnormal in conjunction with a normal cMRI. Conclusion Our data demonstrates that MR spectroscopy is normal in the presence of a normal conventional MRI. Also, MRS was significantly contributing to the diagnosis in 33% (44/154) of patients. Imaging resources may be more economically utilized if MR spectroscopy is directed to patients with abnormal cMRI or high clinical suspicion for a leukodystrophy. Background Retroperitoneal liposarcoma in children is very rare. About less than 10 cases were reported previously. History A 5y/o boy with chief complaint of intermittent pain over right thigh, calf and abdomen in recent 2 weeks following by urine frequency and voiding pain for several days came to our OPD for medical attention. Images Renal ultrasound revealed bilateral hydronephrosis more severe on right side and a 63×60×68 mm heterogenous mass compressing urinary bladder.

CT showed a soft tissue lesion with hypodense content over presacral region, pushing the urinary bladder left anteriorly with peripheral and heterogeneous enhancement; bilateral hydronephrosis with mass compression to right distal ureter was identified. Delayed scan depicted more internal homogenous enhancement without fatty component. Differential diagnosis included Rhabdomyosarcoma, lymphoma, neuroblastoma and liposarcoma. Bone scan and bone marrow showed no metastasis and normal blood cells respectively. Surgical en bloc excision discovered a hard yellowish tumor without invasion to adjacent organs and pathology revealed myxoid and round cell liposarcoma. Right pyeloplasty was also done. Conclusion Although liposarcoma is very rare in children, it should be included in the differential diagnosis; solid pattern in CT is one of the three presentations; association with ureteropelvic junction stricture has not been reported before, it may be a new disease entity or coincidence. Radical excision of tumor usually comes up with complete cure but recurrence may occur. Results CT revealed plaque-like thickening in the parietal peritoneum along the undersurface of the right hemidiaphragm, broad based solid masses located on the visseral surface of the left lobe of liver and the location of spleen ; noduler lesions located in the mesentery of the small bowel; tumor invasion of the falciform ligament and gallbladder bed and massive ascites. Conclusion The CT apperarance of neoplastic involvement of the peritoneum has been described as plaque-like thickening or nodular solid implants in the parietal peritoneum, generally that lining the diaphragm and/or visseral peritoneum, usually in the perihepatic space. The lesions that are detected in pelvis especially in Douglas are named as drop metastasis. The diffuse infiltration of the greater omentum reveals the characteristic omental cake appearence. Ascites often accompanies. Our case had both the plaque-like peritoneal thickening and the noduler mass lesions together with massive ascites. Peritoneal metastasis in Wilm's tumor are generally encountered after surgery as in our case. Before deciding for a treatment it is very important to show local or distant involvement in Wilm's tumor and CT is the single preferred examination.

Unsuspected soft tissue lesions identified on pediatric oncologic patients using whole-body MRI Gye-Yeon Lim, Soo Ah Im, Nak Gyun Chung The Catholic University of Korea Background Whole-body MRI (WB-MRI) has advantages over other imaging modalities for evaluating the possible extent of involvement in pediatric oncologic patients and it has excellent characterization of soft-tissue lesions.
Objective The purpose of this study was to describe unsuspected soft tissue lesions identified at staging and follow up of pediatric oncologic patients using whole body MRI.

Materials and methods A total of 90 patients who performed WB-MRI were enrolled. The images were reviewed and a consensus was reached by two radiologists for the diagnosis. Among these, unsuspected abnormalities were found in 12 patients (6 males, 6 females; mean age, 9 years, age range 5 months-16 years). We retrospectively analyzed the clinical characteristics and WB MRI findings of twelve patients. Diagnoses of the lesions were confirmed by histological examination, medical examination and history of interview, regression of the lesions on follow-up examinations. For comparison three malignant lesions confirmed to be subcutaneous panniculitis T cell like lymphoma were included. Results Disseminated fungal soft tissue abscesses in the muscle and subcutaneous soft tissue were found in one girl with a history of acute lymphocytic leukemia. One patient had focal abscess adjacent to central venous catheter. Other major diagnoses were variable pattern of soft tissue edema (n=5), insect bites (n=3), scratch wound (n=1), and cellulites with an abscess (n=1). Conclusion Unsuspected soft tissue lesions of a variety causes encountered using WB-MRI may confused and mimics malignant involvement in pediatric onologic patients.
Therefore, awareness of this possibility, correlation with clinical history and other imaging findings might help to make the differential diagnosis and avoid unnecessary treatment.

The impact of the new international staging of paediatric neuroblastoma on multi-modality imaging N Tahir, WH Ramsden, AF Scarsbrook Leeds Teaching Hospitals NHS Trust, UK Background The staging classification system for neuroblastoma is due to be updated in the very near future in order to address the older systems' problems such as the inability to compare patients from different countries and the issue of post-surgical staging. Objective To describe the New International Staging System of Neuroblastoma.

To illustrate the range of available imaging techniques and review the spectrum of radiologic and radionuclide appearances in neuroblastoma. To discuss the role of different imaging modalities in the initial diagnosis and disease monitoring process. Content The New International Staging System of Neuroblastoma and the implications for imaging evaluation will be described. Multi-modality imaging techniques including ultrasound, contrast enhanced MR, multi-detector CT, skeletal and radio-labelled metaiodobenzylguanidine (MIBG) scintigraphy and positron emission tomography will be used to illustrate the spectrum of disease. Imaging algorithms for the initial diagnosis/staging and monitoring/detection of suspected disease recurrence will also be presented. Spinal cord compression by metastatic non-CNS malignancy in children R Singaroyan, T Win, A Raghavan Sheffield Children's Hospital, UK Background Spinal cord compression is a rare but serious complication of malignant disease in children. Acute spinal cord dysfunction in children with systemic malignancy is a neurosurgical emergency and is usually due to metastatic spinal cord compression. Neuroblastomas are considered the commonest cause of metastatic spinal disease and sarcomas are considered the commonest cause of spinal cord or nerve root compression in children. Spinal cord compression is a rare presentation of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, occurring in 0.1% to 3.3% of patients. Osteosarcoma, Ewing's sarcoma and rhabdoid tumours are other rare causes of cord compression in children.

Objective To present the imaging features of some of the rare causes of metastatic non-CNS spinal cord compression. Materials and methods Nine cases of spinal cord compression due to non-CNS malignancy were identified in our institution over the last 10 years. The causes included four cases of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, two cases of osteosarcoma, one case of Ewing's sarcoma, one neuroblastoma and one rhabdoid tumour. The imaging consisted of CT, MRI and CT myelogram. Results Though CT picked up the lesions initially MR was confirmatory and showed the extent of disease more clearly. MR was also used in follow up. CT myelogram was useful in cases of prior spinal fixation where the metal work degraded the image quality of CT and MRI. Conclusion Though non-CNS spinal metastasis causing cord compression is rare in the pediatric population knowledge of imaging features is vital to diagnosis and treatment. We present the imaging features of the cases we have encountered in our institution.
Vertebral osteosarcoma pancreas metastasis Serhat Avcu, Huseyin Akdeniz, Harun Arslan, Nursen Toprak, Ozkan Unal Department of Radiology, Yuzuncu Yil University, Van, Turkey

Background Osteosarcoma is the most common malignant bone tumor in children and adolescents, and posseses a high potential of metastasis. The most common sites of metastasis of osteosarcoma are lung, pleura, and bone, the pancreas being extremely rare. Osteosarcoma predominantly involves the metaphysis of tubular bones, and primary vertebral osteosarcoma is a rare entity. Objective We aimed to report a case of primary vertebral osteosarcoma metastatic to pancreas with computerized tomography (CT) findings. Materials and methods The patient was evaluated with abdominal CT. Tru-cut biopsy was performed to the pancreatic mass. Results A 14-years-old boy being followed-up with a diagnosis of primary vertebral osteosarcoma for 6 years applied to our hospital with complaints of nausea, vomitting, diarrhea, melena, and jaundice.

Conclusion Although extremely rare, osteosarcoma metastasis should be included in the differential diagnosis of pancreatic mass lesions especially in those containing calcifications and necrotic areas.

A case of succesfull treatment of infantile myofibromatosis with pulmonary affection, by watchful waiting LS Ording Müller, DFM Avenarius, Tore Stokland University Hospital North Norway Case report After a normal pregnancy a boy was born with extensive cutaneous and pulmonary lesions of infantile myofibromathosis. Imaging of the pediatric patient with acute myeloid leukemia (AML): Findings at presentation and during treatment Jeffrey Traubici, Dimitri Parra, Lillian Sung Hospital for Sick Children/University of Toronto, Canada

Background Acute leukemia is the most frequent type of cancer in childhood. Approximately 15% to 20% of childhood leukemias are of the AML type, with an incidence of 5 to 7 cases per million people per year in the United States. Despite advances, AML accounts for 30% of the deaths secondary to leukemia in children.The term AML refers to a varied group of malignancies arising in the marrow. The etiology and pathogenesis of the disease is complex, involving different genetic mutations resulting in proliferation and increase in the survival of myeloid cells. Other important factors are the exposure to environmental factors (e.g. chemotherapy, ionizing radiation etc) and having certain inherited and acquired conditions (e.g. Down syndrome, Fanconi anemia etc). Treatment of AML can result in significant morbidity. Objective The purpose of this presentation is to illustrate the imaging findings in AML at presentation as well as to demonstrate the various complications of treatment. Materials and methods After obtaining institutional ethics board approval, a database of AML patients was accessed and pertinent imaging studies assessed. Results In the last 9 years (January 2000-December 2008), 90 new cases of AML had been diagnosed at our institution. Using various modalities (radiographs, ultrasound, computed tomography and magnetic resonance imaging), we have observed abnormalities at presentation including parenchymal lung disease, infiltration of solid viscera, osteomyelitis, soft tissue infections and bone marrow abnormalities. During treatment we had seen multiples complication including fungal infections of different organs, neutropenic enterocolitis, typhlitis, abscesses, deep venous thrombosis and hepatic veno-occlusive disease. Conclusion There is a wide spectrum of imaging findings seen in seen in pediatric patients with AML. Some are seen at presentation and others are the sequelae of intense treatment. Familiarity with the appearances will aid the pediatric radiologist in the imaging of patients with AML.

Focal nodular hyperplasia of the liver after treatment of neuroblastoma Berna Oguz, Ilkay Idilman, Musturay Karcaaltincaba, Mithat Haliloglu Department of Radiology, Hacettepe University, Ankara, Turkey

Background Focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH) is a benign hepatic tumor that is uncommon in children. An increased incidence of FNH has been described in oncology patients after completion of tumor therapy. Its development may be related to the vascular damage induced by such therapy. Objective We present MRI findings of a child who developed FNH after receiving chemotherapy for primary disease of neuroblastoma. Materials and methods A boy with right surrenal mass had been diagnosed with neuroblastoma at 2 years of age. He had been underwent surgery and received antineoplastic therapy. He was in remission for 8 years. When the patient was 10 years of age, thorax CT for the evaluation of fever and productive cough revealed solid masses in the upper part of the liver. Magnetic resonance imaging was performed to evaluate the liver lesions and to rule out metastasis. Results The lesions were isointense to slightly hyperintense on T2weighted images, isointense to slightly hypointense to liver on T1weighted images. A small central scar of the largest diameter lesion was hyperintense on T2-weighted images. After contrast administration, the lesions highly enhanced homogenously during the arterial phase and became isointense during the portal venous phase. The central scar of the largest lesion demonstrated delayed enhancement. Malignant lesions, in contrast, are almost always hyperintense on T2-weighted images, typically hypointense on unenhanced T1-weighted images and delayed images and hyperintense during the arterial phase and have a variable appearance during the portal venous phase. FNH of the liver was diagnosed because of the typical appearance of the lesions on MRI. Conclusion FNH should be considered in a patient with a history of malignancy treated with chemotherapy who develops hepatic masses. Recognition of the characteristic imaging appearance will aid in the correct diagnosis and might obviate the need for biopsy.

Fast and accurate magnetic resonance imaging protocol to document central nervous system and sinus abnormalities prior to pediatric hematopoietic stem Henrique M Lederman, Eliane L Donato, Felipe G Barbosa, Cinthya R Carvalho, Gilberto Szarf, RV Gouveia, Victor G Zecchin, Valeria C Ginani Federal University of Sao Paulo, Sao Paulo, Brazil

Background Patients undergoing bone marrow transplant (BMT) may have several risk factors for infectious complications. Active asymptomatic sinus infection at the time of admission carries a high risk and must be treated prior to initiation of the conditioning regimen. Central nervous system (CNS) complications are also common after BMT and may be related to the chemotherapy and/or radiation given to treat the underlying malignancy or may be specifically due to transplant-related complications. The only effective way to sort it out is having an underlying evaluation prior to the admission for transplant. The current standard method used to evaluate the patients pre-BMT is head and sinus computerized tomography (CT). However, this method is not accurate to demonstrate subtle CNS abnormalities and white matter diseases. Moreover, CT exposes the patient to radiation, which varies from 0.02 to 0.1 Gy. Head magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), despite much better sensitivity for white matter abnormalities, cannot be routinely used due to the higher cost and longer duration of the exam. Objective Our objective was to design a fast, inexpensive and radiation-free MRI-based protocol to document any sinus or brain abnormalities that could mandate intervention or change the preparative high-dose chemotherapy regimen. Materials and methods Analysis of the feasibility of the head and sinuses MRI protocol: axial T1, axial Flair and coronal T2. Results The duration of the examination in this protocol was six minutes. The brain MRI images were highly sensitive for CNS abnormalities and the coronal T2 was excellent to diagnose sinus disease Conclusion Our MRI protocol is sufficient for the evaluation of patients referred for BMT with reduced examination time and no radiation to the patient.

Technical approach to T1 mapping in childhood abdominal tumours Teresa Totman, Oystein Olsen Great Ormond Street Hospital NHS Trust, UK Background T1 measurements are important for quantification of tissue perfusion, which is of interest in childhood tumours. However, technical restraints may hinder reliable T1 mapping. Objective To develop and compare the performance of two different techniques for T1 mapping in the abdomen Materials and methods We developed MRI spoiled gradient echo sequences for T1 mapping using 1) variable time of inversion with prospective respiratory gating, and 2) variable flip angle with a single breath-hold acquisition. The technical feasibility was assessed for five patients in each group. We then went on to compare T1 values using both techniques in five subsequent patients. Results Both techniques were feasible, and detailed results will be presented.
Conclusion T1 mapping is feasible and valid even in abdominal MRI in infants and young children.

The incremental value of 18F-FDG PET-CT compared to contrast enhanced CT in the evaluation of paediatric Hodgkin's disease N Tahir, F Chowdhury, AF Scarsbrook Leeds Teaching Hospitals NHS Trust, UK Background PET-CT combines functional and morphologic data and has been shown to increase diagnostic accuracy in Hodgkin's disease. Objective To review our initial experience of the additional information provided by 18F-FDG PET-CT above conventional CT in adolescent patients with Hodgkin's disease. Materials and methods Consecutive paediatric patients with Hodgkin's disease who underwent PET-CT imaging as part of disease assessment were identified retrospectively from an institutional database. The findings were compared with the corresponding diagnostic quality CT performed within 2 weeks of the PET-CT. Results During the study period from May 2007 to January 2009, 33 PET-CT scans were performed in 15 patients. Three scans were omitted from the study because no corresponding CT scan was available for comparison. The age range of the patients was 9 years to 19 years. Tweenty-three (77%) scans were performed to assess response to treatment and 7 (23%) scans for baseline staging. PET-CT provided additional information in 24 (80%) scans: in 10 (33%) scans PET-CT more accurately characterised the presence of disease or detected additional sites of disease and in 11 (37%) scans PET-CT confirmed remission in patients with residual structural abnormality. PET-CT identified additional sites of extra-nodal disease in 3 (10%) cases: 1 bone involvement, 1 splenic involvement, 1 chest wall involvement. There was one false positive PET-CT finding where suspected marrow involvement was negative on bone marrow biopsy. Conclusion PET-CT provided significant additional information in 80% of scans compared to conventional imaging and correctly identified additional extra-nodal disease in 10%. This was instrumental in guiding subsequent patient management.
